target_language_example: Elle adore passer du temps avec son petit-enfant.
native_language_example: She loves spending time with her grandchild.

additional_notes: It combines 'petit' (small) and 'fils' (son), literally translating to 'little son', indicating a familial relationship spanning two generations.
target_language_example: Mon petit-fils a cinq ans.
native_language_example: My grandson is five years old.

additional_notes: Used to describe a female romantic partner. It can be used informally among friends or in more formal contexts.
target_language_example: Il a une nouvelle petite amie.
native_language_example: He has a new girlfriend.

additional_notes: Commonly used in informal settings. In French, 'petite' means small or little, which can also give a sense of endearment here.
target_language_example: Il a invité sa petite copine au cinéma.
native_language_example: He invited his girlfriend to the movies.

additional_notes: Used to refer to a small spoon typically used for stirring hot beverages or eating desserts. Commonly found in household and café settings.
target_language_example: Peux-tu me passer la petite cuillère ?
native_language_example: Can you pass me the teaspoon?

additional_notes: In French culture, the 'petite souris' is the equivalent of the 'tooth fairy,' an imaginary mouse that collects children's teeth from under the pillow and leaves a token gift.
target_language_example: La petite souris est passée cette nuit et a laissé une pièce d'un euro.
native_language_example: The tooth fairy came last night and left a one-euro coin.

additional_notes: Used to refer to a female sibling who is younger. French uses adjectives that change form to agree with the noun they describe, so 'petite' agrees with 'sœur.'
target_language_example: Ma petite sœur adore dessiner.
native_language_example: My younger sister loves to draw.

additional_notes: When talking about family, you can say 'ma petite-fille' for 'my granddaughter'.
target_language_example: Ma petite-fille vient chez nous le week-end.
native_language_example: My granddaughter comes to our house on the weekend.

additional_notes: Used to refer to people who are not wealthy or powerful, emphasizing their modest lifestyle. It can be used sympathetically to acknowledge the hard work and challenges they face.
target_language_example: Les petites gens travaillent dur tous les jours pour joindre les deux bouts.
native_language_example: Ordinary people work hard every day to make ends meet.

additional_notes: Used to indicate that the specifics of a situation are not important or significant. Often utilized to convey nonchalance or to downplay the importance of a detail.
target_language_example: Peu importe ce qu'il a dit, allons-y.
native_language_example: It doesn't matter what he said, let's go.

additional_notes: Used to indicate that something is irrelevant or insignificant to the situation.
target_language_example: Peu importe ce qu'il dit.
native_language_example: It doesn't matter what he says.

additional_notes: Used to describe gradual progression or change, indicating that something happens slowly over time.
target_language_example: Peu à peu, elle apprend le français.
native_language_example: Little by little, she is learning French.

additional_notes: Often used in religious contexts to refer to a community believed to have a special relationship with God.
target_language_example: Les Israélites ont longtemps été considérés comme le peuple élu.
native_language_example: The Israelites have long been considered the chosen people.

additional_notes: The term "peur bleue" can be directly translated to "blue fear," and is used to describe an intense level of fear, greater than the usual sense of fear. Often used in storytelling or when recounting scary experiences.
target_language_example: J'ai eu une peur bleue quand j'ai entendu le bruit étrange dans la maison.
native_language_example: I was terrified when I heard the strange noise in the house.

additional_notes: Used to express uncertainty or a possibility. Often starts a sentence; if so, inversion (Peut-être viendra-t-il) or "que" + normal word order (Peut-être que...) is possible. Always hyphenated.
target_language_example: Peut-être que nous irons à la plage demain.
native_language_example: Maybe we will go to the beach tomorrow.

additional_notes: Used to refer to valuable gemstones, often used in jewelry like diamonds, rubies, sapphires, and emeralds.
target_language_example: Elle a acheté une bague avec une pierre précieuse.
native_language_example: She bought a ring with a gemstone.

additional_notes: Commonly used in games or when making a choice by chance. 'Pile' refers to the tails side, and 'face' refers to the heads side of the coin.
target_language_example: On tire à pile ou face pour décider qui commence.
native_language_example: We're flipping heads or tails to decide who starts.

additional_notes: Often involves family or friends gathering to enjoy a meal outside, frequently in a park or nature setting.
target_language_example: Nous allons faire un pique-nique au parc.
native_language_example: We are going to have a picnic in the park.

additional_notes: A casual activity typically involving food enjoyed outdoors, often in a park or another pleasant natural setting.
target_language_example: Nous allons pique-niquer au parc demain.
native_language_example: We are going to have a picnic in the park tomorrow.

meaning: to have a fit or to freak out.
additional_notes: This expression is informal and used to describe someone suddenly losing their temper or having an emotional outburst. It's similar to saying someone is 'losing it' or 'going ballistic' in English.
target_language_example: Quand il a découvert la vérité, il a piqué une crise.
native_language_example: When he discovered the truth, he freaked out.

additional_notes: This is often used when referring to official documents like passports, national ID cards, or driver's licenses that serve to verify a person's identity in official contexts.
target_language_example: Pour entrer, vous aurez besoin de montrer une pièce d'identité.
native_language_example: To enter, you will need to show an identification document.

additional_notes: Used to refer to physical currency, specifically coins as opposed to bills (billets).
target_language_example: J'ai besoin d'une pièce de monnaie pour le distributeur.
native_language_example: I need a coin for the vending machine.

additional_notes: This term is commonly used to refer to performances in places like theaters, and it emphasizes the art form and script involved. It's a cultural term that reflects the importance of theater in French-speaking areas.
target_language_example: J'ai vu une belle pièce de théâtre hier soir.
native_language_example: I saw a beautiful play last night.

additional_notes: This phrase is quite formal and may be considered old-fashioned in modern French. It is now mostly replaced by 'pardon' or 'comment?'.
target_language_example: Plait-il, pouvez-vous répéter?
native_language_example: Pardon me, can you repeat that?

additional_notes: This phrase is mainly found in formal or very polite contexts, such as in old-fashioned speech or in literary works. Today, you would more commonly say 'pardon?' or 'comment?' when you didn't hear something.
target_language_example: Plaît-il, monsieur?
native_language_example: Excuse me, sir?

additional_notes: The term 'pleine lune' is used similarly to 'full moon' in English, referring to the lunar phase when the moon is fully illuminated and appears as a complete circle in the sky.
target_language_example: Nous allons camper pendant la pleine lune.
native_language_example: We are going to camp during the full moon.

additional_notes: This expression is an idiomatic way to describe very heavy rain in French, equivalent to saying 'it's pouring' or 'it's raining cats and dogs' in English.
target_language_example: Il pleut des cordes depuis ce matin.
native_language_example: It's been raining heavily since this morning.

additional_notes: Used to describe a situation where there is a heavy downpour or rain that comes in large quantities, similar to 'it's raining cats and dogs' in English.
target_language_example: Aujourd'hui, il pleut à verse !
native_language_example: Today, it's pouring down!

additional_notes: The phrase 'plus besoin' is used when the necessity for something has ceased. It often appears in negative sentences to contrast with previous needs.
target_language_example: Je n'ai plus besoin de ton aide.
native_language_example: I no longer need your help.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to express that something or someone is no longer necessary or required. It often precedes a noun or verb in the infinitive.
target_language_example: Il n'y a plus besoin de lui rappeler.
native_language_example: There's no more need to remind him.

additional_notes: Placed directly before a noun to express a larger quantity (plus de pain = more bread). In the negative structure “ne … plus de”, it means “no more / no longer any” (Je n’ai plus de temps = I have no more time).
target_language_example: Je voudrais plus de café, s'il vous plaît.
native_language_example: I'd like more coffee, please.

additional_notes: It's often used to express that something is increasing or has an additional dimension beyond what's already mentioned. Can be used to indicate continuity or to strengthen a point.
target_language_example: Il a travaillé dur, et il veut travailler plus encore.
native_language_example: He worked hard, and he wants to work even more.

additional_notes: Used to indicate approximation, agreement with some reservation, or as a response to questions about how something is going.
target_language_example: Ça va ? Plus ou moins.
native_language_example: How are you? More or less.

additional_notes: Used in negative contexts to indicate the absence of people, often following a previous expectation or presence.
target_language_example: Il n'y a plus personne dans la salle.
native_language_example: There is no one left in the room.

additional_notes: Used to compare two items or qualities, indicating that one has more of a certain characteristic than the other.
target_language_example: Il est plus grand que son frère.
native_language_example: He is taller than his brother.

additional_notes: Used to describe an intensified state or condition compared to the past.
target_language_example: Ils sont unis plus que jamais.
native_language_example: They are united more than ever.

additional_notes: Commonly used to schedule or postpone activities to a future time. It indicates that something will happen after the present moment.
target_language_example: Je le ferai plus tard.
native_language_example: I will do it later.

additional_notes: Used to describe actions or events that occur more than once, indicating repetition or frequency.
target_language_example: J'ai regardé ce film plusieurs fois.
native_language_example: I have watched that movie several times.

additional_notes: Used to emphatically refuse or show strong opposition to an idea or action. Often hyperbolic, not meant literally.
target_language_example: Je porterais cette tenue ? Plutôt mourir !
native_language_example: Wear that outfit? I'd rather die!

additional_notes: Used to describe the act of grasping and shaking someone's hand as a greeting, agreement, or gesture of goodwill.
target_language_example: Ils ont scellé l'accord avec une poignée de main.
native_language_example: They sealed the deal with a handshake.

additional_notes: Used to talk about shared features, characteristics, or interests between people or things.
target_language_example: Ils ont beaucoup de points communs.
native_language_example: They have a lot of common points.

additional_notes: Commonly used to describe the beginning of a journey or the initial stage of a plan or process.
target_language_example: Le point de départ de notre voyage sera Paris.
native_language_example: The starting point of our trip will be Paris.

additional_notes: Used in medical contexts to refer to stitches used to close a wound or surgical incision.
target_language_example: Le médecin a fait un point de suture pour refermer la plaie.
native_language_example: The doctor put in a stitch to close the wound.

additional_notes: This term is used to indicate someone's opinion or perspective on a particular subject. It is commonly used in discussions, debates, or when expressing one's standpoint.
target_language_example: Du point de vue de l'artiste, le tableau est un chef-d'œuvre.
native_language_example: From the artist's point of view, the painting is a masterpiece.

additional_notes: Commonly used to describe a person's weakness, it can also refer to a flaw in an argument or system.
target_language_example: Son manque de patience est son point faible.
native_language_example: His lack of patience is his weak point.

additional_notes: Often used to emphasize that a decision or opinion is final and not open to further discussion.
target_language_example: Tu ne regarderas pas la télé ce soir. Point final.
native_language_example: You will not watch TV tonight. And that's final.

additional_notes: Often used to highlight an individual's skills or the best features of an object or idea.
target_language_example: Son point fort, c'est sa capacité à résoudre des problèmes rapidement.
native_language_example: His strength is his ability to solve problems quickly.

additional_notes: Commonly used to describe walking or standing quietly to avoid making noise, or in a context of dance where the toes are pointed for balance and form.
target_language_example: Elle marche sur la pointe des pieds pour ne pas réveiller le bébé.
native_language_example: She walks on tiptoe so as not to wake the baby.

additional_notes: Commonly used in culinary contexts when discussing ingredients in recipes or traditional dishes.
target_language_example: Je vais ajouter des pois chiches à la salade.
native_language_example: I'm going to add chickpeas to the salad.

additional_notes: The term is used to describe a small, often domestic fish that is typically orange or reddish but not necessarily 'red' as the adjective suggests. Commonly kept in bowls or aquariums as pets.
target_language_example: J'ai un poisson rouge chez moi.
native_language_example: I have a goldfish at home.

additional_notes: It's the common term used in French for a potato, and is literally translated as 'apple of the earth'.
target_language_example: Je vais acheter des pommes de terre pour le dîner.
native_language_example: I am going to buy some potatoes for dinner.

additional_notes: Used to refer to the popular snack made by popping kernels of corn, commonly enjoyed at movies or as a snack.
target_language_example: J'adore manger du pop-corn au cinéma.
native_language_example: I love eating popcorn at the cinema.

additional_notes: It's often used when referring to entering a building for the first time or indicating an access point.
target_language_example: Je t'attendrai devant la porte d'entrée.
native_language_example: I'll wait for you in front of the front door.

additional_notes: Used to describe an object believed to bring good fortune.
target_language_example: Elle a toujours un porte-bonheur dans son sac.
native_language_example: She always has a lucky charm in her bag.

additional_notes: Used to refer to a small purse or wallet mostly for carrying coins and sometimes small amounts of paper money or cards. It is a compound noun formed from 'porter' (to carry) and 'monnaie' (money or currency).
target_language_example: J'ai oublié mon porte-monnaie à la maison.
native_language_example: I forgot my wallet at home.

additional_notes: Used to describe people, objects, or actions believed to cause unfortunate events or bad luck.
target_language_example: Ce chat noir porte malheur.
native_language_example: This black cat brings bad luck.

additional_notes: Used in legal contexts when someone reports an offense or dispute to the police or legal authorities, formally requesting action to be taken.
target_language_example: Elle a décidé de porter plainte contre son voisin pour tapage nocturne.
native_language_example: She decided to file a complaint against her neighbor for disturbing the peace.

additional_notes: Used to describe efforts that have been successful or are starting to show positive results, similar to saying something is paying off in English.
target_language_example: Après des mois de travail acharné, son projet commence enfin à porter ses fruits.
native_language_example: After months of hard work, his project is finally starting to bear fruit.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used to emphasize how strongly two people resemble each other, typically in terms of appearance.
target_language_example: Il est le portrait craché de son père.
native_language_example: He is the spitting image of his father.

meaning: 'to cause a problem' or 'to be problematic'.
additional_notes: This phrase is used to express when someone or something is causing or might cause issues, difficulties, or complications.
target_language_example: Ce règlement pourrait poser problème aux étudiants.
native_language_example: This regulation could cause problems for the students.

additional_notes: Often used to describe conditions relating to mental health after a traumatic event, such as 'post-traumatic stress disorder' (PTSD).
target_language_example: Il souffre de stress post-traumatique après l'accident.
native_language_example: He suffers from post-traumatic stress after the accident.

additional_notes: A place where police officers work and the public can report crimes or seek help. Commonly found in towns and cities.
target_language_example: Je vais au poste de police pour déclarer la perte de mon portefeuille.
native_language_example: I am going to the police station to report the loss of my wallet.

additional_notes: Literally translates to 'pot of wine', historically alluding to a gift given as persuasion. It carries a negative connotation of corruption.
target_language_example: Il a reçu un pot-de-vin pour changer sa décision.
native_language_example: He received a bribe to change his decision.

additional_notes: This idiomatic expression compares a timid or scared person to a wet hen, which behaves nervously and timidly.
target_language_example: Ne sois pas une poule mouillée, essaye cette montagne russe !
native_language_example: Don't be a coward, try this roller coaster!

additional_notes: Used when something is figurative or not meant to be taken literally, often to offer a clarification or to express approximation.
target_language_example: Il est, pour ainsi dire, le chef de l’équipe.
native_language_example: He is, so to speak, the leader of the team.

additional_notes: Used to highlight a contradiction or exception following a previous statement, similar to saying 'that being said' or 'despite this'.
target_language_example: Il a fait très froid aujourd'hui, mais nous avons décidé de sortir pour autant.
native_language_example: It was very cold today, but we decided to go out nonetheless.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to introduce a condition or limitation. It often precedes a clause that expresses what the speaker believes to be true based on current information, and it is typically followed by a verb in the subjunctive mood.
target_language_example: Pour autant que je sache, elle est en vacances.
native_language_example: As far as I know, she is on vacation.

additional_notes: Used to express limited knowledge about a topic and to indicate that there might be more information unknown to the speaker.
target_language_example: Pour autant que je sache, il n'est pas encore arrivé.
native_language_example: As far as I know, he hasn't arrived yet.

additional_notes: This phrase is commonly used to specify the reason behind a particular situation or event, often found in official or written communication.
target_language_example: La réunion a été annulée pour cause de mauvais temps.
native_language_example: The meeting was canceled due to bad weather.

additional_notes: Often used to introduce the first point or idea in a list or sequence.
target_language_example: Pour commencer, je voudrais remercier tout le monde d'être ici.
native_language_example: To start with, I would like to thank everyone for being here.

additional_notes: Used to indicate permanence or a definitive action, implying that something is final and won't change.
target_language_example: Il a quitté la ville pour de bon.
native_language_example: He left the city for good.

additional_notes: Used to confirm the truth or sincerity of a statement, often in informal conversations. It can also convey surprise or disbelief.
target_language_example: C'est pour de vrai, je vais déménager à Paris !
native_language_example: It's for real, I'm going to move to Paris!

additional_notes: Used when summarizing something lengthy or complex but only providing key details.
target_language_example: Pour faire court, nous avons décidé de ne pas aller en vacances cette année.
native_language_example: To make a long story short, we decided not to go on vacation this year.

additional_notes: Typically used to introduce the last point or step in a list, presentation, or argument.
target_language_example: Pour finir, je voudrais remercier tous les participants.
native_language_example: Finally, I would like to thank all the participants.

additional_notes: Used to express an intense reason, often employed in pleas or expressions of frustration or irritation. It can also be used affectionately.
target_language_example: Pour l'amour de Dieu, arrête de faire ça!
native_language_example: For the love of God, stop doing that!

additional_notes: Often used to express something that is true only in the current time frame, but may change.
target_language_example: Pour l'instant, je ne peux pas venir.
native_language_example: For now, I can't come.

additional_notes: This term is used to describe the majority or the main part of a group or situation.
target_language_example: Les élèves, pour la plupart, étaient satisfaits du résultat.
native_language_example: The students, for the most part, were satisfied with the result.

additional_notes: Often used to express commitment or permanence, particularly in contexts like marriage vows or close friendships.
target_language_example: Ils se sont promis amour et fidélité pour la vie.
native_language_example: They promised each other love and fidelity for life.

additional_notes: Used to highlight or emphasize a particular situation, often suggesting that it is surprising or noteworthy. It can express a sense of suddenly realizing or acknowledging something.
target_language_example: Pour le coup, il avait raison.
native_language_example: In this case, he was right.

additional_notes: Used to express that the current situation is temporary and may change. It emphasizes what is true or applicable right now.
target_language_example: Je n'ai pas faim pour le moment.
native_language_example: I'm not hungry for now.

additional_notes: Used when referring to other remaining things or aspects not previously specified.
target_language_example: Nous avons terminé le rapport, mais pour le reste, nous verrons demain.
native_language_example: We finished the report, but as for the rest, we'll see tomorrow.

additional_notes: Used when giving one's own viewpoint or stance on a matter, often to contrast with others' opinions.
target_language_example: Pour ma part, je préfère rester chez moi ce soir.
native_language_example: As for me, I prefer staying home tonight.

additional_notes: Used to introduce a less harsh, or more precise, way of describing something that was just mentioned. Often follows a statement to suggest a different perspective or to enhance clarity.
target_language_example: Il est extrêmement talentueux, pour ne pas dire un génie.
native_language_example: He is extremely talented, not to say a genius.

additional_notes: Requires the use of the subjunctive mood, as it expresses intention or a desired outcome. Typically followed by a clause indicating the intended goal.
target_language_example: Je t'ai donné ce livre pour que tu puisses étudier.
native_language_example: I gave you this book so that you can study.

additional_notes: Used to question the purpose or reason behind an action or event.
target_language_example: Tu veux acheter ça ? Pour quoi faire ?
native_language_example: You want to buy that? For what purpose?

additional_notes: Often used to express that an action was done unnecessarily or without any effect.
target_language_example: Il a crié pour rien.
native_language_example: He shouted for no reason.

additional_notes: Often used informally in conversations to confirm or agree with something positively and with confidence. It carries a slightly less formal tone compared to using the phrase 'certainement'.
target_language_example: Tu viens à la fête ce soir ? Pour sûr !
native_language_example: Are you coming to the party tonight? For sure!

additional_notes: Used to express an indefinite period of time, often in a romantic or emotional context.
target_language_example: Je t'aimerai pour toujours.
native_language_example: I will love you forever.

additional_notes: Used to highlight that something is atypical or not the usual occurrence, often carrying a tone of mild surprise or relief.
target_language_example: Pour une fois, il est arrivé à l'heure.
native_language_example: For once, he arrived on time.

additional_notes: Used when expressing personal truth or sincerity, often prefacing a frank or straightforward statement.
target_language_example: Pour être honnête, je n'aime pas vraiment ce film.
native_language_example: To be honest, I don't really like this movie.

additional_notes: This expression is often used to show openness or willingness to try or consider something.
target_language_example: On pourrait aller au cinéma ce soir. - Pourquoi pas ?
native_language_example: We could go to the movies tonight. - Why not?

meaning: to sue or to take legal action.
additional_notes: Commonly used in legal contexts when one party registers a legal complaint against another, initiating a court case.
target_language_example: Elle a décidé de poursuivre l'entreprise en justice pour harcèlement.
native_language_example: She decided to sue the company for harassment.

additional_notes: Often used to introduce a condition that must be met for the action in the main clause to happen, usually followed by the subjunctive mood.
target_language_example: Je viendrai pourvu que tu sois là.
native_language_example: I will come provided that you are there.

additional_notes: Used to describe one's initial romantic experience, often with a sense of nostalgia or innocence. Commonly referenced in literary and conversational contexts.
target_language_example: Elle était mon premier amour.
native_language_example: She was my first love.

additional_notes: Used to describe the chief government officer in many countries, often having significant influence over domestic and foreign policy.
target_language_example: Le premier ministre a annoncé de nouvelles réformes.
native_language_example: The prime minister announced new reforms.

additional_notes: Often used to describe something that is most important or noticeable in a given context.
target_language_example: La question du climat est au premier plan du débat actuel.
native_language_example: The issue of climate is at the forefront of the current debate.

additional_notes: Typically used in travel contexts, indicating superior amenities and service compared to standard options.
target_language_example: Nous avons voyagé en première classe pour plus de confort.
native_language_example: We traveled in first class for more comfort.

additional_notes: This phrase is commonly used to express that something is happening for the first time. It can be used both in literal and metaphorical contexts.
target_language_example: C'est ma première fois en France.
native_language_example: This is my first time in France.

additional_notes: Used to refer to a woman holding the position of prime minister. In French, gender-specific titles are important, so the word changes from "premier ministre" for a male to "première ministre" for a female.
target_language_example: Emmanuel Macron a choisi sa première ministre.
native_language_example: Emmanuel Macron chose his female prime minister.

additional_notes: Often used in grammatical contexts to describe narration or perspective, as in a narrative told from the speaker's own point of view using 'I' or 'we'.
target_language_example: Le livre est écrit à la première personne.
native_language_example: The book is written in the first person.

additional_notes: Used when someone is surprised by something unexpected, often with a connotation of not being prepared for it.
target_language_example: Il m'a pris au dépourvu avec sa question.
native_language_example: He caught me off guard with his question.

meaning: to take someone at their word.
additional_notes: This expression is used when you accept what someone says as true or literal, often stressing that you expect them to follow through with their statements.
target_language_example: Il a dit qu'il viendrait, donc je le prends au mot.
native_language_example: He said he would come, so I'm taking him at his word.

additional_notes: Used to express the act of giving importance or consideration to something or someone.
target_language_example: Il faut prendre au sérieux ses conseils.
native_language_example: You must take his advice seriously.

additional_notes: It is often used to describe how someone reacts to news, advice, or a situation in a positive and constructive way.
target_language_example: Il a pris bien la nouvelle.
native_language_example: He took the news well.

additional_notes: Often used to formally end a meeting or conversation, indicating that someone is leaving or departing. It can be used in both personal and professional contexts.
target_language_example: Il a pris congé de ses collègues après la réunion.
native_language_example: He took leave of his colleagues after the meeting.

additional_notes: Used to describe the process of realizing or understanding something, often a gradual coming to terms with a new idea or piece of information.
target_language_example: Il a pris conscience des conséquences de ses actes.
native_language_example: He became aware of the consequences of his actions.

meaning: 'to get in touch' or 'to make contact'.
additional_notes: Used when initiating contact with someone, whether by phone, email, or in person. Often applied in social, professional, or formal contexts.
target_language_example: Il est important de prendre contact avec le client avant la réunion.
native_language_example: It's important to get in touch with the client before the meeting.

additional_notes: Often used in informal contexts or in a broader sense than strictly academic courses, such as taking driving lessons or other types of classes.
target_language_example: Elle a décidé de prendre cours de piano pour se détendre.
native_language_example: She decided to take piano classes to relax.

meaning: 'to put on airs' or 'to act superior'.
additional_notes: Used to describe someone who is pretending or striving to appear more sophisticated or of higher status than they truly are. Often carries a negative connotation.
target_language_example: Elle prend des airs depuis qu'elle a cette nouvelle voiture.
native_language_example: She puts on airs since she got that new car.

additional_notes: Used to indicate the initiation of actions or steps, especially in a formal or official context.
target_language_example: Le gouvernement doit prendre des mesures pour protéger l'environnement.
native_language_example: The government must take steps to protect the environment.

additional_notes: Used to describe enjoying oneself, often through leisure activities or simply by relaxing.
target_language_example: Le weekend, je veux juste prendre du bon temps avec mes amis.
native_language_example: On the weekend, I just want to have a good time with my friends.

additional_notes: Used when someone is increasing in body weight, often in the context of diet or health discussions.
target_language_example: Après les fêtes, il a pris du poids.
native_language_example: After the holidays, he gained weight.

meaning: 'to take a step back' or 'gain perspective'.
additional_notes: Used to describe stepping back from a situation to evaluate it more objectively.
target_language_example: Il est important de prendre du recul avant de prendre une décision importante.
native_language_example: It's important to take a step back before making an important decision.

additional_notes: This term is often used when you are responsible for something or when someone or something is under your care or supervision.
target_language_example: Je vais prendre en charge le projet.
native_language_example: I will take charge of the project.

meaning: to consider or take into account.
additional_notes: Used to indicate that certain factors or elements should be considered or included in decision-making or analysis.
target_language_example: Nous devons prendre en compte les opinions de tout le monde.
native_language_example: We must take into account everyone's opinions.

additional_notes: Used when evaluating or considering different aspects or factors before making a decision.
target_language_example: Nous devons prendre en considération toutes les options avant de décider.
native_language_example: We need to take into account all the options before deciding.

additional_notes: Typically used when someone is discovered doing something they shouldn't be doing, often in the context of crime or rule-breaking.
target_language_example: Le voleur a été pris en flagrant délit par la police.
native_language_example: The thief was caught in the act by the police.

additional_notes: Used when you want to describe the action of capturing an image with a camera. It's similar to saying 'take a picture of' or 'photograph' someone or something in English.
target_language_example: Elle a pris en photo le coucher de soleil.
native_language_example: She took a photo of the sunset.

meaning: 'to take example from' or 'to model oneself after'.
additional_notes: Used when suggesting that someone should learn from another person's behavior or actions. Often used to give advice or suggest improvement.
target_language_example: Tu devrais prendre exemple sur ton frère.
native_language_example: You should model yourself after your brother.

additional_notes: Used both literally for objects igniting and figuratively for someone becoming very angry or enthusiastic.
target_language_example: La maison a pris feu à cause d'un court-circuit.
native_language_example: The house caught fire because of a short circuit.

additional_notes: Often used to talk about the ending of events, projects, situations, or time periods. Related to the English phrase 'to end' or 'to come to a close.'
target_language_example: La réunion va prendre fin bientôt.
native_language_example: The meeting will come to an end soon.

additional_notes: Used to describe something beginning to develop or become more clearly defined, often referring to plans, ideas, or actual physical structures.
target_language_example: Le projet commence à prendre forme.
native_language_example: The project is starting to take shape.

additional_notes: Used when someone is exposed to cold weather or drafts that may lead to getting sick.
target_language_example: J'ai peur de prendre froid si je sors sans manteau.
native_language_example: I'm afraid of catching a cold if I go out without a coat.

meaning: to watch out or be careful.
additional_notes: Used to advise someone to be cautious or alert about a potential danger or risk.
target_language_example: Prends garde au chien méchant.
native_language_example: Watch out for the mean dog.

additional_notes: Used when someone wants to go outside for a short walk or to relax and enjoy the outdoors.
target_language_example: Je vais prendre l'air avant le dîner.
native_language_example: I'm going to get some fresh air before dinner.

additional_notes: This phrase suggests urgency or the necessity to leave a place quickly, often due to fear, danger, or avoiding consequences.
target_language_example: Les voleurs ont pris la fuite avant l'arrivée de la police.
native_language_example: The thieves ran away before the police arrived.

meaning: 'to take the initiative' or 'to take control'.
additional_notes: This expression can be used both literally, to describe physically taking someone's hand, and metaphorically, to indicate taking control of a situation or helping someone. It implies leadership or guidance.
target_language_example: Il a pris la main lors de la réunion pour proposer des solutions.
native_language_example: He took control during the meeting to propose solutions.

prendre la main dans le sac

target_language_multi_word_term: prendre la main dans le sac
additional_notes: This expression is similar to the English idiom of catching someone 'red-handed', indicating witnessing someone in the middle of committing an act they shouldn't be doing.
target_language_example: Elle l'a pris la main dans le sac en train de tricher.
native_language_example: She caught him red-handed cheating.

additional_notes: Used to describe the act of evaluating a situation, item, or person to understand them better. It's common in strategic or evaluative discussions.
target_language_example: Il faut prendre la mesure des défis avant de décider.
native_language_example: We need to assess the challenges before deciding.

additional_notes: This phrase is used when someone begins to speak in a formal or public context, such as meetings, speeches, or debates.
target_language_example: Jean a décidé de prendre la parole lors de la réunion.
native_language_example: Jean decided to speak at the meeting.

additional_notes: Used when someone goes out of their way or makes extra effort to do something. It can express appreciation or emphasis on the effort made.
target_language_example: Elle a pris la peine de nous écrire une longue lettre.
native_language_example: She took the trouble to write us a long letter.

meaning: to take over or to take the reins.
additional_notes: It is typically used in situations where a responsibility or duty is transferred from one person to another, such as in jobs or family responsibilities. It can imply continuity or succession.
target_language_example: Elle va prendre la relève après mon départ.
native_language_example: She will take over after I leave.

additional_notes: Used to express beginning a journey by any mode of transportation, though often implies driving.
target_language_example: Nous allons prendre la route tôt demain matin.
native_language_example: We are going to hit the road early tomorrow morning.

additional_notes: Used to express annoyance or frustration with a person or situation that is overly complicated or troublesome. Often used in informal contexts.
target_language_example: Il me prend vraiment la tête avec ses histoires.
native_language_example: He's really annoying me with his stories.

meaning: 'to take over' or 'to take the baton'.
additional_notes: Used when someone else continues a task, responsibility, or duty that another person started.
target_language_example: Après que Marie ait terminé son discours, Jacques a pris le relai pour répondre aux questions.
native_language_example: After Marie finished her speech, Jacques took over to answer questions.

additional_notes: Used when someone assumes the responsibilities or duties that were previously held by someone else. Often used in contexts involving teamwork or shifting duties.
target_language_example: Après son départ, j'ai dû prendre le relais.
native_language_example: After he left, I had to take over.

meaning: 'to take the wheel' or 'to start driving'.
additional_notes: Often used when someone begins to drive a car or in situations where someone assumes control. Can also be used metaphorically.
target_language_example: Quand il a pris le volant, nous avons enfin pu partir.
native_language_example: When he took the wheel, we were finally able to leave.

meaning: to take charge or take control.
additional_notes: This phrase is commonly used in contexts where someone assumes leadership or control of a situation, often in work or operational settings.
target_language_example: Après le départ du manager, Pierre a pris les commandes de l'équipe.
native_language_example: After the manager left, Pierre took charge of the team.

additional_notes: Often used in contexts where people are speculating or making informal predictions about the outcome of an event. It implies a willingness to formally or informally predict and place a wager on an outcome.
target_language_example: Ils sont prêts à prendre les paris pour savoir qui gagnera la course.
native_language_example: They are ready to take bets on who will win the race.

additional_notes: Used to describe the act of assessing a situation or making plans based on an evaluation.
target_language_example: Nous devons prendre mesure de la situation avant de décider.
native_language_example: We need to take measure of the situation before deciding.

additional_notes: Used to indicate the act of writing down information or acknowledging an important point. Common in academic and professional situations.
target_language_example: Je vais prendre note des points importants de la réunion.
native_language_example: I will take note of the important points from the meeting.

additional_notes: Typically used when discussing participation in events, activities, or discussions.
target_language_example: Elle a décidé de prendre part à la réunion.
native_language_example: She decided to take part in the meeting.

meaning: 'to take a side' or 'to take a stand'.
additional_notes: This term is often used when someone decides to support a particular person or viewpoint over another in a discussion or conflict.
target_language_example: Il a pris parti pour son ami dans la dispute.
native_language_example: He took his friend's side in the argument.

additional_notes: Often used when someone unexpectedly becomes frightened due to a surprising or alarming situation.
target_language_example: Il a pris peur en voyant l'orage arriver.
native_language_example: He got scared when he saw the storm coming.

additional_notes: Often used in formal contexts to indicate the start of an event or for someone to sit down. It's a versatile phrase useful for both casual and formal situations.
target_language_example: La réunion prendra place dans la salle de conférence à 15 heures.
native_language_example: The meeting will take place in the conference room at 3 PM.

meaning: to enjoy or take pleasure in.
additional_notes: Used to express enjoyment or satisfaction derived from an activity, event, or experience.
target_language_example: Elle prend beaucoup de plaisir à lire des romans.
native_language_example: She takes great pleasure in reading novels.

additional_notes: Used when someone stops working permanently, usually due to age or end of career.
target_language_example: Il a décidé de prendre sa retraite à 65 ans.
native_language_example: He decided to retire at 65.

additional_notes: Used when talking about caring for someone or something or being careful with something. Can refer to both physical care and metaphorical or emotional care.
target_language_example: Il faut prendre soin de sa santé.
native_language_example: You must take care of your health.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to express care or responsibility towards someone or something. It can imply both physical and emotional care.
target_language_example: Elle prend soin de son jardin tous les jours.
native_language_example: She takes care of her garden every day.

additional_notes: Used to suggest not rushing through an activity or task. Encourages a careful, relaxed approach.
target_language_example: Il vaut mieux prendre son temps pour faire attention aux détails.
native_language_example: It's better to take your time to pay attention to details.

additional_notes: Used when someone is caught doing something wrong or unexpected at the exact moment it happens.
target_language_example: Il a été pris sur le fait en train de tricher à l'examen.
native_language_example: He was caught in the act cheating on the exam.

additional_notes: Used in social contexts, similar to saying 'grab a drink' in English. It implies going out for drinks with friends, colleagues, or acquaintances.
target_language_example: On pourrait prendre un verre ce soir.
native_language_example: We could have a drink tonight.

additional_notes: Refers to the set of annual international awards bestowed in several categories by Swedish and Norwegian institutions, celebrating significant contributions and achievements.
target_language_example: Marie Curie a reçu le prix Nobel deux fois.
native_language_example: Marie Curie received the Nobel Prize twice.

additional_notes: Used to politely request someone to perform an action, often seen on notices or in formal situations.
target_language_example: Prière de fermer la porte.
native_language_example: Please close the door.

additional_notes: Used to refer to any food product made from milk, such as cheese, yogurt, and butter.
target_language_example: Je suis allergique aux produits laitiers.
native_language_example: I am allergic to dairy products.

additional_notes: A preliminary version of a law that is proposed and discussed before it is potentially approved and enacted.
target_language_example: Le projet de loi sera discuté au parlement la semaine prochaine.
native_language_example: The bill will be discussed in parliament next week.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used in cards, messages, or directly spoken to someone who is sick or convalescing. It conveys best wishes for their health.
target_language_example: Je te souhaite un prompt rétablissement.
native_language_example: I wish you a speedy recovery.

additional_notes: This term is commonly used to indicate that a space or object is owned by an individual or an organization and not for public use. It is often seen on signs to keep unauthorized persons away.
target_language_example: Ce terrain est une propriété privée.
native_language_example: This land is private property.

additional_notes: Used to ask someone to focus or be attentive to a particular thing or situation. It is commonly used in educational settings or when one needs to be alert and fully engaged.
target_language_example: Il est important de prêter attention aux détails.
native_language_example: It is important to pay attention to the details.

additional_notes: Often used in ceremonial or legal contexts, such as in courts or official capacities, to assure sincere commitment or truthfulness.
target_language_example: Le président doit prêter serment avant de commencer son mandat.
native_language_example: The president must take an oath before starting his term.

additional_notes: Formal and polite; commonly found in signs, written requests, or customer-service language. Less frequent in casual speech, where alternatives like "Est-ce que je peux…" are preferred.
target_language_example: Puis-je vous aider ?
native_language_example: May I help you?

additional_notes: The term is used to describe a type of knitted garment that is worn over the upper body for warmth. It does not refer to cardigans, which have an open front.
target_language_example: J'ai acheté un nouveau pull-over pour l'hiver.
native_language_example: I bought a new sweater for the winter.

additional_notes: This is considered vulgar and should be used cautiously. It's often used to express strong emotions like frustration or annoyance. It can precede a noun to add intensity, much like using a strong expletive in English.
target_language_example: C'est un putain de problème.
native_language_example: That's a fucking problem.

additional_notes: 'Putain de' is informal and considered vulgar; it's used for emotional emphasis. Common in spoken French, but should be used cautiously due to its crudeness.
target_language_example: C'était un putain de bon concert.
native_language_example: It was a damn good concert.

additional_notes: Père Noël is a figure of folklore who traditionally brings gifts on Christmas Eve. The term is used similarly to 'Santa Claus' in English-speaking countries.
target_language_example: Les enfants attendent avec impatience la visite du père Noël.
native_language_example: The children eagerly await Santa Claus's visit.

additional_notes: Literally translates to 'blow the fuses', akin to overloading a circuit, but it figuratively means to get very angry or frustrated.
target_language_example: Quand il a vu le désordre, il a complètement pété les plombs.
native_language_example: When he saw the mess, he completely lost it.

additional_notes: The term is often used when discussing geography, climate, or the polar region. It functions like its English equivalent to denote the Earth's northernmost point.
target_language_example: Le pôle Nord est recouvert de glace toute l'année.
native_language_example: The North Pole is covered with ice all year round.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used in polite or formal settings, such as when ordering food or making inquiries about future plans or possessions.
target_language_example: Au restaurant : Qu'aurez-vous comme dessert ?
native_language_example: At the restaurant: What will you have for dessert?

additional_notes: This phrase is typically used to ask someone about their preferences or choices in hypothetical situations. It's often utilized in more formal or polite contexts.
target_language_example: Qu'auriez-vous fait à ma place ?
native_language_example: What would you have done in my place?

additional_notes: This question is in the imperfect tense, used when talking about an ongoing situation in the past. It is a formal question due to the use of 'vous'.
target_language_example: Qu'aviez-vous comme voiture à l'époque ?
native_language_example: What car did you have at the time?

additional_notes: Used when asking about the presence of something or the reason for a situation. It can be used in various contexts, from checking if something is present to inquiring about a problem or situation.
target_language_example: Qu'est-ce qu'il y a dans ce sac?
native_language_example: What is there in this bag?

additional_notes: Placed at the start of a question to ask about an object, idea, or action. Follow it with subject + verb: Qu'est-ce que + subject + verb ? Spoken more than written questions with inversion.
target_language_example: Qu'est-ce que tu fais ce soir ?
native_language_example: What are you doing tonight?

additional_notes: Commonly used to ask for the identity or nature of a thing, often when you are unsure or learning. It's a staple in beginner conversations.
target_language_example: Qu'est-ce que c'est ce bruit?
native_language_example: What is that noise?

additional_notes: Used in questions to ask about the subject of a verb, often inquiring the cause or reason for something.
target_language_example: Qu'est-ce qui se passe ici ?
native_language_example: What is happening here?

meaning: "what did you have", in past historic tense.
additional_notes: This phrase structure is typically used in formal or literary contexts. The past historic tense (passé simple) is generally found in written narratives. In spoken French, you'll use the passé composé instead, such as 'qu'avez-vous eu ?' for the same meaning in a more conversational setting.
target_language_example: Qu'eûtes-vous pour le dîner hier soir ?
native_language_example: What did you have for dinner last night?

additional_notes: Used to ask what exists or is happening in a certain place or situation. Often used when inquiring about the presence or state of something.
target_language_example: Qu'y a-t-il dans le sac?
native_language_example: What is there in the bag?

additional_notes: This phrase is used to introduce a clause that represents a hypothetical or unexpected situation, often emphasizing a contrast with the main clause.
target_language_example: Quand bien même il pleuvrait, nous irons à la plage.
native_language_example: Even if it rains, we will go to the beach.

additional_notes: Used to express a concession, an unexpected result, or to emphasize a point, often reflecting surprise or persistence.
target_language_example: Il pleuvait, mais nous sommes sortis quand même.
native_language_example: It was raining, but we went out anyway.

additional_notes: It is used to introduce a topic or person and to provide specific information or opinion about them.
target_language_example: Quant à moi, je préfère rester ici.
native_language_example: As for me, I prefer to stay here.

additional_notes: This term is a compound number, formed by combining 'quarante' (forty) and 'cinq' (five). It follows the standard structure for French compound numbers.
target_language_example: Il a quarante-cinq ans.
native_language_example: He is forty-five years old.

additional_notes: The term is a composite number word. "Quarante" means "forty," and "huit" means "eight." The hyphen is used as a connector between the tens and units in French.
target_language_example: Il y a quarante-huit élèves dans la classe.
native_language_example: There are forty-eight students in the class.

additional_notes: Used to describe a time period of 15 minutes. Commonly used when telling time or estimating durations.
target_language_example: Je reviens dans un quart d'heure.
native_language_example: I'll be back in fifteen minutes.

additional_notes: Used to describe the primary location or central office from which an organization or operation is directed.
target_language_example: L'entreprise a déménagé son quartier général à Paris.
native_language_example: The company moved its headquarters to Paris.

additional_notes: The French number system for numbers between 60 and 99 can be confusing to learners since it involves a base 20 system. 'Quatre-vingt' means 4 times 20, or 80. This term can be extended with the numbers 1-19 to form the numbers 81-99, like 'quatre-vingt-un' for 81.
target_language_example: Il y a quatre-vingt élèves dans cette école.
native_language_example: There are eighty students in this school.

additional_notes: In French, numbers between 80 and 99 are constructed using a vigesimal system (base 20). For 90, 'quatre-vingts' (80) plus 'dix' (10).
target_language_example: J'ai quatre-vingt-dix minutes pour terminer ce travail.
native_language_example: I have ninety minutes to finish this work.

additional_notes: French numbers 80-99 are based on a vigesimal (base-20) system, so 'quatre-vingts' literally translates to 'four twenties'.
target_language_example: Il y a quatre-vingts élèves dans l'école.
native_language_example: There are eighty students in the school.

additional_notes: Used to emphasize the abundance or high quantity of something. Often indicates surprise or admiration.
target_language_example: Que de gens à la fête !
native_language_example: So many people at the party!

additional_notes: An expression of surprise or frustration, often used to rhetorically emphasize confusion or disbelief. It is typically used in informal contexts.
target_language_example: Que diable fais-tu ici ?
native_language_example: What on earth are you doing here?

additional_notes: This phrase is commonly used to indicate a lack of absolute certainty about information being given. It's a way to moderately express what you believe to be true.
target_language_example: Que je sache, elle n'est pas encore arrivée.
native_language_example: As far as I know, she hasn't arrived yet.

additional_notes: Used to express a belief or thought. Often part of a larger construction where it introduces something that the speaker assumes or suspects.
target_language_example: C'est possible que tu crois que j'ai tort, mais je suis sûr de ce fait.
native_language_example: It's possible that you believe I'm wrong, but I'm sure of this fact.

additional_notes: Used in informal contexts to ask someone about their desires or preferences. It is a direct question and uses inversion, swapping the subject ('you') and verb ('want').
target_language_example: Que veux-tu pour le dîner ?
native_language_example: What do you want for dinner?

additional_notes: Used to politely inquire about someone's desires or requests. Appropriate for formal or respectful situations.
target_language_example: Que voulez-vous boire ?
native_language_example: What would you like to drink?

additional_notes: Used when expressing regret or disappointment about an event or situation.
target_language_example: Oh non ! Il a arrêté le projet ? Quel dommage !
native_language_example: Oh no! He stopped the project? What a shame!

additional_notes: Used in formal or literary contexts to introduce a clause about hypothetical or uncertain conditions in the past. It usually appears in subjunctive mood constructions.
target_language_example: Quel que fût son choix, il avait des conséquences.
native_language_example: Whatever his choice was, it had consequences.

additional_notes: Used to express a sense of indifference or general applicability to all options or conditions.
target_language_example: Quel que soit le résultat, je serai content.
native_language_example: Whatever the result, I will be happy.

additional_notes: This phrase is used when asking someone to describe current or expected weather conditions.
target_language_example: Quel temps fait-il aujourd'hui ?
native_language_example: What's the weather like today?

additional_notes: Used to ask someone about their age in an informal context. Use it among friends and peers.
target_language_example: Quel âge as-tu, Marie ?
native_language_example: How old are you, Marie?

additional_notes: This is a straightforward question to inquire about the current time. It is often used in casual conversation.
target_language_example: Excusez-moi, quelle heure est-il ?
native_language_example: Excuse me, what time is it?

additional_notes: Indefinite pronoun for an unidentified person. In negative statements French typically uses "personne" instead of "pas quelqu'un." Before adjectives add "de": "quelqu'un de gentil" (someone nice).
target_language_example: Il y a quelqu'un à la porte.
native_language_example: There is someone at the door.

additional_notes: Used to talk about an unknown or non-specific object or idea. In a negative sentence it is replaced by 'rien' (e.g., 'Je ne veux rien'). Often appears in offers or questions.
target_language_example: Tu veux quelque chose à boire ?
native_language_example: Do you want something to drink?

additional_notes: Used to refer to an unspecified or unknown location.
target_language_example: J'ai laissé mes clés quelque part dans la maison.
native_language_example: I left my keys somewhere in the house.

additional_notes: Used to indicate a small or slight degree of something. Often used to soften statements or express nuance.
target_language_example: Je suis quelque peu fatigué aujourd'hui.
native_language_example: I am somewhat tired today.

additional_notes: Use 'quelque temps' when referring to a general period of time without specifying an exact duration. It can be used in various contexts, such as waiting or experiencing something temporarily.
target_language_example: Il faut que j'attende ici pendant quelque temps.
native_language_example: I have to wait here for some time.

additional_notes: Typically refers to a small, unspecified number of feminine nouns previously mentioned or understood from context. The masculine equivalent is 'quelques-uns'.
target_language_example: J'ai pris quelques-unes des pommes.
native_language_example: I took a few of the apples.

additional_notes: Refers to an unspecified number of items or people, but clearly more than one. It can be used with countable nouns, for example to indicate not all, but a selection.
target_language_example: Parmi les invités, quelques-uns sont arrivés tôt.
native_language_example: Among the guests, a few arrived early.

additional_notes: Typically used to inquire about the person speaking, especially in phone conversations or other settings where the speaker is not visible.
target_language_example: Excusez-moi, qui parle ?
native_language_example: Excuse me, who is speaking?

additional_notes: Typically used to introduce additional, usually important or impactful, information or arguments. It's common in both formal and informal settings.
target_language_example: Il fait froid dehors; qui plus est, il va neiger cette nuit.
native_language_example: It's cold outside; what's more, it's going to snow tonight.

additional_notes: Often used in contexts where the subject of a verb is not specifically known. Similar in usage to 'quiconque.'
target_language_example: Qui que ce soit, il doit respecter les règles.
native_language_example: Whoever it is, they must follow the rules.

additional_notes: Used to indicate any person or individual, regardless of identity.
target_language_example: Qui que ce soit peut participer à la réunion.
native_language_example: Whoever it may be can join the meeting.

additional_notes: Used when the speaker is uncertain or when the result of a situation is uncertain. It can reflect doubt, speculation, or resignation about the unknown.
target_language_example: Peut-être qu'il viendra demain. Qui sait ?
native_language_example: Maybe he'll come tomorrow. Who knows?

additional_notes: The term originates from a military challenge and is used to signify being watchful or on guard. It describes a state of vigilance and readiness to notice or act upon something.
target_language_example: Le garde était sur le qui vive toute la nuit.
native_language_example: The guard was on the alert all night.

additional_notes: This phrase is used when you see someone unexpectedly or want to draw attention to someone's arrival.
target_language_example: Ah, qui voilà ! C'est toi, Jean !
native_language_example: Ah, look who's here! It's you, Jean!

additional_notes: Used metaphorically to describe abandonning a team, project, or situation, especially in tough times.
target_language_example: En pleine crise, il a décidé de quitter le navire.
native_language_example: In the middle of the crisis, he decided to abandon ship.

additional_notes: Commonly used as an informal greeting among friends, and indicates curiosity about recent happenings.
target_language_example: Salut, quoi de neuf ?
native_language_example: Hi, what's new?

additional_notes: Often used in informal settings when someone feels overwhelmed by a continuous stream of tasks or demands.
target_language_example: Tu as oublié de faire la vaisselle? Quoi encore?
native_language_example: You forgot to do the dishes? What now?

additional_notes: Used when considering options or when faced with indecision. Often used in situations when asking for suggestions or guidance.
target_language_example: Je ne sais pas quoi faire.
native_language_example: I don't know what to do.

additional_notes: This phrase is mostly used in literary contexts or formal writing. It suggests that the outcome remains unaffected by previous conditions or uncertainties.
target_language_example: Quoi qu'il en fût, ils ont continué leur voyage.
native_language_example: Regardless of what happened, they continued their journey.

additional_notes: Used to shift focus or transition between ideas, regardless of previous statements.
target_language_example: Quoi qu'il en soit, nous devrons partir bientôt.
native_language_example: Anyway, we'll need to leave soon.

additional_notes: Expresses indifference or broad applicability across conditions. Often followed by a verb in subjunctive mood to indicate uncertainty or non-specificity.
target_language_example: Quoi que tu fasses, je te soutiendrai.
native_language_example: No matter what you do, I will support you.

additional_notes: Used to express any possibility or to indicate no specific preference or requirement. Often used in negative constructions to emphasize a lack of limitation.
target_language_example: Je ne veux rien, quoi que ce soit.
native_language_example: I don't want anything, whatever it is.

additional_notes: Used to introduce clauses that express a contrast or concession.
target_language_example: Il a réussi, quoique malade.
native_language_example: He succeeded, although he was sick.

additional_notes: Used both in the literal sense of recounting tales and sometimes to suggest embellishing or making things up.
target_language_example: Il aime raconter des histoires à ses amis.
native_language_example: He likes to tell stories to his friends.

additional_notes: Used when someone needs a reminder or to recall information that they have forgotten.
target_language_example: Je vais relire mes notes pour rafraîchir ma mémoire.
native_language_example: I will reread my notes to refresh my memory.

additional_notes: 'Raisin de Corinthe' is the French term for currants, which are small, dried, seedless grapes often used in baking and cooking. Not to be confused with 'raisins' which refer to regular dried grapes.
target_language_example: Je vais ajouter des raisins de Corinthe au gâteau.
native_language_example: I will add currants to the cake.

additional_notes: It's a common term used in cooking and baking recipes. Despite the direct translation, it refers to the dried fruit we call raisins in English.
target_language_example: J'aime ajouter des raisins secs dans mes céréales.
native_language_example: I like adding raisins to my cereal.

additional_notes: Used to describe the most significant purpose or role something or someone has.
target_language_example: Son travail est sa raison d'être.
native_language_example: His work is his reason for being.

additional_notes: This term is often used in medical, educational, or formal contexts regarding sex and health. It's important to approach this term with respect, as it can pertain to sensitive topics.
target_language_example: Ils ont discuté des risques associés à un rapport sexuel non protégé.
native_language_example: They discussed the risks associated with unprotected sexual intercourse.

additional_notes: Used to indicate a connection or reference to something. It can be similar to saying 'regarding' or 'with respect to' in English.
target_language_example: J'ai une question en rapport à votre dernier email.
native_language_example: I have a question regarding your last email.

additional_notes: In French, 'raton' means 'small rat', and 'laveur' means 'washer', indicating the raccoon's distinctive habit of washing its food before eating.
target_language_example: J'ai vu un raton laveur dans le jardin.
native_language_example: I saw a raccoon in the garden.

additional_notes: Used when someone needs to compensate for time that was not used efficiently or to catch up on things that were delayed.
target_language_example: Après les vacances, il faut rattraper le temps perdu au travail.
native_language_example: After the holidays, we have to make up for lost time at work.

additional_notes: Used when someone has to put aside their ego or dignity to achieve or accept something.
target_language_example: Il a dû ravaler sa fierté et demander de l'aide.
native_language_example: He had to swallow his pride and ask for help.

meaning: A 'ray of sunshine', used both literally and metaphorically.
additional_notes: Metaphorically refers to someone or something that brings happiness. Literally, it refers to a beam of light from the sun.
target_language_example: Elle est toujours un rayon de soleil dans ma journée.
native_language_example: She is always a ray of sunshine in my day.

meaning: to turn back or retrace one's steps.
additional_notes: Commonly used when someone has decided to go back the way they came. This can be used literally, like when lost or taking a wrong direction, or metaphorically, like changing one's decision.
target_language_example: Nous avons dû rebrousser chemin après avoir pris un mauvais tournant.
native_language_example: We had to turn back after taking a wrong turn.

additional_notes: Usually implies strong disapproval, anger, or judgment from the person giving the look. Literally translates to 'black look'.
target_language_example: Elle m'a lancé un regard noir quand j'ai oublié son anniversaire.
native_language_example: She gave me a dirty look when I forgot her birthday.

additional_notes: Used to indicate authority, responsibility, or domain someone or something is under. Common in legal and administrative language.
target_language_example: Cette affaire relève de la compétence du tribunal.
native_language_example: This case falls under the jurisdiction of the court.

additional_notes: Used when someone wants to reconsider or question the correctness or acceptability of a decision, statement, or belief.
target_language_example: Il est important de remettre en cause nos préjugés.
native_language_example: It is important to question our prejudices.

additional_notes: Often used when discussing ideas, beliefs, or decisions that need to be reassessed. It implies a need for further analysis or critique rather than accepting things at face value.
target_language_example: Les chercheurs ont décidé de remettre en question les résultats de l'étude.
native_language_example: The researchers decided to question the study's results.

meaning: to put someone in their place.
additional_notes: This phrase is used when correcting someone's behavior or attitude. It's often used when someone needs to be reminded of their position or boundaries in a situation.
target_language_example: Il a essayé de me critiquer, mais je l'ai rapidement remis à sa place.
native_language_example: He tried to criticize me, but I quickly put him in his place.

meaning: to cheer up or boost morale.
additional_notes: Used when someone is feeling down or discouraged to help improve their mood.
target_language_example: J'ai acheté un cadeau pour lui remonter le moral.
native_language_example: I bought a gift to cheer him up.

additional_notes: Used to express the concept of reversing the progression of time, often in discussions about history or hypothetical situations involving time travel.
target_language_example: Si je pouvais remonter le temps, je changerais beaucoup de choses.
native_language_example: If I could go back in time, I would change a lot of things.

additional_notes: This expression is used to describe someone who is doing everything possible to achieve a goal or find something, indicating a very thorough and determined effort.
target_language_example: Elle a remué ciel et terre pour retrouver son chat perdu.
native_language_example: She left no stone unturned to find her lost cat.

additional_notes: Used for both informal meet-ups with friends or formal appointments, such as with doctors or for business.
target_language_example: J'ai un rendez-vous chez le médecin demain.
native_language_example: I have a doctor's appointment tomorrow.

additional_notes: Typically used in formal or professional settings when one needs to provide details about an event or situation to others. It can also mean to realize or become aware of something when used reflexively as 'se rendre compte.'
target_language_example: Il doit rendre compte de ses actions au conseil.
native_language_example: He must report on his actions to the board.

additional_notes: This phrase is typically used in formal contexts to honor a person, their work, or their memory. It can be used both for living individuals and those who have passed away.
target_language_example: Ils ont organisé une cérémonie pour rendre hommage aux victimes.
native_language_example: They organized a ceremony to pay tribute to the victims.

additional_notes: This phrase is typically used in contexts where someone is returning a favor or retaliating in a similar manner. It's about balancing actions or exchanging similar responses.
target_language_example: Elle m'a prêté de l'argent, donc je vais lui rendre la pareille et l'aider à déménager.
native_language_example: She lent me money, so I'm going to repay her in kind by helping her move.

meaning: to do a favor or help someone.
additional_notes: Used when you offer help or assistance to someone else. It can also reflect a kind gesture or a supportive action.
target_language_example: Il m'a rendu service en me prêtant sa voiture.
native_language_example: He did me a favor by lending me his car.

additional_notes: 'Rendre visite' is used when referring to visiting people. For visiting places, the verb 'visiter' is used instead.
target_language_example: Je vais rendre visite à ma grand-mère ce week-end.
native_language_example: I am going to visit my grandmother this weekend.

meaning: to return to normal or back in order.
additional_notes: This phrase is used when things have settled or been fixed after a period of disorder or chaos.
target_language_example: Après la tempête, tout est rentré dans l'ordre.
native_language_example: After the storm, everything returned to normal.

additional_notes: Commonly used to describe physical collisions, but also metaphorically to describe aggressive behavior or confrontation.
target_language_example: La voiture a rentré dedans un arbre.
native_language_example: The car crashed into a tree.

additional_notes: Used when someone wants to make a fresh start or redo something from the beginning without relying on past work or experiences.
target_language_example: Après l'échec de notre projet, nous avons décidé de repartir à zéro.
native_language_example: After our project failed, we decided to start from scratch.

additional_notes: Used to express sympathy or condolence, often found on gravestones or in obituaries. It is the French equivalent of the English expression 'rest in peace.'
target_language_example: Il est parti trop tôt, mais qu'il repose en paix.
native_language_example: He left too soon, but may he rest in peace.

additional_notes: Used to express a wish for the deceased to find peace in the afterlife. Often seen in obituaries, eulogies, and funeral services.
target_language_example: Nous espérons que vous reposez en paix.
native_language_example: We hope you rest in peace.

additional_notes: Commonly used to describe food that is quickly prepared and served, typically in a fast-food restaurant.
target_language_example: Nous allons manger dans un restaurant de restauration rapide ce soir.
native_language_example: We are going to eat at a fast food restaurant tonight.

additional_notes: Typically used to suggest that the outcome of a situation is uncertain or yet to be determined.
target_language_example: Le succès de ce projet reste à voir.
native_language_example: The success of this project remains to be seen.

additional_notes: Used literally when someone stops breathing temporarily, or metaphorically to express suspense or anticipation.
target_language_example: Il a retenu son souffle en attendant les résultats de l'examen.
native_language_example: He held his breath while waiting for the exam results.

additional_notes: This phrase is used when one has to start over after encountering a setback or when progress is not as expected, resulting in starting from the initial position again.
target_language_example: Après l'échec de notre projet, c'est retour à la case départ.
native_language_example: After the failure of our project, it's back to square one.

additional_notes: Often used when discussing revisiting a decision or subject matter after some time has passed, usually indicating a change of opinion or re-assessment.
target_language_example: Il a promis de ne pas revenir sur sa décision.
native_language_example: He promised not to backtrack on his decision.

additional_notes: Often used to indicate going back to a previous state, location, or point in a conversation.
target_language_example: Je dois revenir à la maison avant le dîner.
native_language_example: I need to return home before dinner.

additional_notes: It is used in buildings to refer to the street-level floor. In French, 'rez' means 'level' and 'chaussée' means 'road', so it literally translates to 'the level of the road'.
target_language_example: Nous habitons au rez-de-chaussée.
native_language_example: We live on the ground floor.

additional_notes: This term is used to express that nothing else compares to or equals the subject being discussed. It can convey a sense of uniqueness or excellence.
target_language_example: Il n'y a rien de tel qu'une promenade matinale pour se réveiller.
native_language_example: There's nothing like a morning walk to wake you up.

additional_notes: Used to emphasize the absence or lack of something. Often used in negative sentences to express total negation.
target_language_example: Je n'ai rien du tout à dire.
native_language_example: I have nothing at all to say.

additional_notes: It emphasizes exclusivity or limitation, often used to highlight that something is sufficient on its own.
target_language_example: Il a dépensé 100 euros, rien que pour des bonbons.
native_language_example: He spent 100 euros just on candies.

meaning: 'nothing to be done' or 'can't be helped'.
additional_notes: Often used to indicate that something is beyond one's control or cannot be changed, similar to saying 'it is what it is' in English.
target_language_example: Il n'y a rien à faire, il continuera à pleuvoir toute la journée.
native_language_example: There's nothing to be done, it will keep raining all day.

additional_notes: This expression is informal and slightly vulgar. It is used to convey strong indifference or lack of concern. Learners should be cautious when using it due to its coarse nature.
target_language_example: Il n'a rien à foutre des règles.
native_language_example: He doesn't give a damn about the rules.

additional_notes: Used to express that two things are unrelated. Often used to deny or clarify misunderstandings.
target_language_example: Ce qu'il dit n'a rien à voir avec la réalité.
native_language_example: What he's saying has nothing to do with reality.

meaning: 'to laugh out loud' or 'to belly laugh'.
additional_notes: Used to describe a loud, hearty laughter that is very expressive and heartfelt.
target_language_example: Elle a ri à gorge déployée à la blague.
native_language_example: She laughed out loud at the joke.

additional_notes: Refers to the most common type of rice, often used as a staple food in many dishes around the world. It is rice that has had its husk, bran, and germ removed.
target_language_example: Je voudrais du poulet avec du riz blanc.
native_language_example: I would like chicken with white rice.

additional_notes: Typically worn at formal events, such as galas, weddings, or fancy dinners.
target_language_example: Elle a acheté une nouvelle robe de soirée pour le bal.
native_language_example: She bought a new evening gown for the ball.

additional_notes: This genre involves narratives centered around a crime, often a murder, and the subsequent investigation. It features typical elements such as detectives, suspects, and a mystery to be solved.
target_language_example: J'aime lire des romans policiers, surtout ceux d'Agatha Christie.
native_language_example: I like reading detective novels, especially those by Agatha Christie.

additional_notes: The phrase is a compound noun and is used to refer to the cosmetic product applied to the lips to add color or texture.
