target_language_example: Les scientifiques étudient les trous noirs pour comprendre l'univers.
native_language_example: Scientists study black holes to understand the universe.

additional_notes: This phrase is used when someone is being critical or nitpicking about minor issues.
target_language_example: Il trouve toujours à redire sur mon travail.
native_language_example: He always finds fault with my work.

additional_notes: Common reply to questions about wellbeing (e.g., « Ça va ? – Très bien. »). Also used to intensify an adjective or verb to praise quality or performance.
target_language_example: Tu parles français très bien !
native_language_example: You speak French very well!

additional_notes: Used to express strong agreement with what someone else has said, often in an informal setting.
target_language_example: Il fait vraiment chaud aujourd'hui. - Tu l'as dit!
native_language_example: It's really hot today. - You said it!

additional_notes: In French, the structure is different; the person being missed is the subject, and the person who is missing them is the object. This can be confusing for English speakers because it flips the positions of the subject and the object compared to English.
target_language_example: Quand tu es parti, tu me manques beaucoup.
native_language_example: When you left, I missed you a lot.

additional_notes: Literally means 'you speak', but it can be used sarcastically to express doubt or disbelief, similar to saying 'yeah, right!' in English. Context will usually clarify the intended meaning.
target_language_example: "Tu as gagné à la loterie? Tu parles!"
native_language_example: "You won the lottery? Yeah, right!"

meaning: "are you talking about" or "do you mean"
additional_notes: This phrase is used when clarifying or confirming the subject of a conversation. It often precedes the topic under discussion.
target_language_example: Tu parles de quoi ?
native_language_example: What are you talking about?

additional_notes: Used to indicate the ability to speak or permission to speak, in an informal context. 'Tu' is the informal 'you', and 'peux' is the verb 'pouvoir' (to be able to) conjugated in present tense for 'tu'.
target_language_example: Tu peux parler plus fort, s'il te plaît?
native_language_example: Can you speak louder, please?

additional_notes: Used to check if someone is aware of something or as a casual filler at the start or middle of a sentence.
target_language_example: Tu sais, je pense qu’il vaut mieux partir tôt.
native_language_example: You know, I think it’s better to leave early.

additional_notes: Used to introduce a surprising or noteworthy point in conversation, often indicating a shift or emphasis in the dialogue.
target_language_example: Tu sais quoi ? Je vais déménager à Paris !
native_language_example: You know what? I'm moving to Paris!

additional_notes: This phrase is commonly used when you're doing an activity just to fill a time gap, not necessarily because it's worthwhile or interesting.
target_language_example: J'ai lu un livre pour tuer le temps en attendant le bus.
native_language_example: I read a book to kill time while waiting for the bus.

additional_notes: Used to describe someone who kills people in exchange for money. Common in crime fiction and film contexts.
target_language_example: Le personnage principal du film était un tueur à gages impitoyable.
native_language_example: The main character of the movie was a ruthless hitman.

additional_notes: Common term in French-speaking countries for a mobile phone. Often interchangeable with 'portable'.
target_language_example: Je viens d'acheter un nouveau téléphone mobile.
native_language_example: I just bought a new mobile phone.

additional_notes: Refers to a mobile communication device that can be used for calls, messages, and accessing the internet. Distinguished from fixed-line telephones.
target_language_example: Je ne trouve pas mon téléphone portable.
native_language_example: I can't find my mobile phone.

additional_notes: Often used with a specific person's name or title following 'à'. Use it to indicate making a phone call to a specific person or place.
target_language_example: Je vais téléphoner à Marie ce soir.
native_language_example: I am going to call Marie tonight.

additional_notes: This term is often used in legal contexts to refer to someone who directly observes an event, providing firsthand testimony.
target_language_example: Le témoin oculaire a décrit l'accident en détail.
native_language_example: The eyewitness described the accident in detail.

additional_notes: In political contexts, 'tête de liste' refers to the lead candidate in an electoral list system, often the person expected to win or lead the party if successful.
target_language_example: Elle a été nommée tête de liste pour les prochaines élections.
native_language_example: She was appointed as the lead candidate for the upcoming elections.

meaning: a private conversation between two people.
additional_notes: Often used to suggest privacy and intimacy in a conversation, like a private chat or discussion. It can also imply a friendly or intimate meeting.
target_language_example: Nous avons besoin d'un tête à tête pour discuter de ce problème.
native_language_example: We need a tête-à-tête to discuss this issue.

additional_notes: Used to describe something that is bound to happen over time, regardless of when exactly it will occur.
target_language_example: Il découvrira la vérité tôt ou tard.
native_language_example: He will discover the truth sooner or later.

meaning: another / one more / a different one
additional_notes: Used to ask for or mention an additional or different item or person. Can be placed before a noun or used alone as a pronoun.
target_language_example: Je peux avoir un autre verre, s'il vous plaît ?
native_language_example: Can I have another glass, please?

additional_notes: Commonly used in idiomatic expressions such as 'd'un coup' meaning 'all at once', or 'donner un coup de main' meaning 'to give a hand'.
target_language_example: Il m'a donné un coup sur l'épaule.
native_language_example: He gave me a hit on the shoulder.

additional_notes: Used to talk about a non-specific day in the future when something might happen.
target_language_example: Nous devrions aller à Paris un de ces jours.
native_language_example: We should go to Paris one of these days.

additional_notes: Used when talking about doing something at an undefined point in the future. It often carries a casual backdrop, suggesting no immediate urgency.
target_language_example: On ira au cinéma un de ces quatre.
native_language_example: We'll go to the movies one of these days.

additional_notes: Used to specify a large quantity of countable items. Useful for both formal and informal contexts.
target_language_example: Il y a un grand nombre de personnes au concert.
native_language_example: There are a large number of people at the concert.

additional_notes: It can signify a vague future time or refer to a specific day in the past.
target_language_example: Un jour, je visiterai Paris.
native_language_example: One day, I will visit Paris.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to describe doing something sequentially, typically when referring to people or objects being handled or occurring individually and in sequence.
target_language_example: Les enfants entrent dans la classe un par un.
native_language_example: The children enter the classroom one by one.

additional_notes: Used to talk about a small quantity or degree, or to soften statements/requests.
target_language_example: Je parle un peu français.
native_language_example: I speak a little French.

additional_notes: Used to refer to a small quantity of a non-countable or abstract noun. Often followed by a noun to indicate the substance or matter being referred to.
target_language_example: Je voudrais un peu de lait dans mon café.
native_language_example: I would like a little bit of milk in my coffee.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used to express a need or inquiry about having a short amount of time to do something.
target_language_example: J'ai besoin d'un peu de temps pour finir ce projet.
native_language_example: I need a little time to finish this project.

additional_notes: This expression is used informally in spoken French to indicate a small degree or amount of something.
target_language_example: Elle est un poil fatiguée aujourd'hui.
native_language_example: She is a bit tired today.

additional_notes: Often used to describe something insignificant or to downplay the importance of an event or object.
target_language_example: C'était un rien, ne t'inquiète pas.
native_language_example: It was nothing, don't worry about it.

additional_notes: Informal expression used to indicate a large amount or number of items. It can be used both literally and figuratively.
target_language_example: Il y a un tas de livres sur la table.
native_language_example: There are a lot of books on the table.

additional_notes: Used to refer to something specific that is being discussed or highlighted. Often implies a noteworthy or particular quality, and can be used to generalize when referring to an example in conversation.
target_language_example: Je n'ai jamais vu un tel désordre!
native_language_example: I've never seen such a mess!

additional_notes: Used when actions or processes are done individually, sequentially, or piece by piece, rather than all at once.
target_language_example: Les enfants sont sortis de la salle un à un.
native_language_example: The children left the room one by one.

additional_notes: Used to indicate an event that occurs a single time.
target_language_example: Je ne l'ai fait qu'une fois.
native_language_example: I did it only once.

additional_notes: Used to indicate a definitive conclusion or resolution to something, implying that there will be no need to return to the issue in the future.
target_language_example: Nous devons régler ce problème une fois pour toutes.
native_language_example: We need to solve this problem once and for all.

additional_notes: Used when asking someone to wait briefly or indicating a need for a momentary pause.
target_language_example: Une minute, s'il vous plaît.
native_language_example: Just a minute, please.

additional_notes: Commonly used to express uncertainty or when something is a mystery.
target_language_example: Il n'est pas là ? Va savoir où il est.
native_language_example: He's not here? Who knows where he is.

additional_notes: This is a strong insult and considered very rude. It is used to tell someone to leave or express extreme annoyance or anger, similar to telling someone off harshly in English.
target_language_example: Il m'a dit de partir, alors je lui ai répondu : 'Va te faire foutre !'
native_language_example: He told me to leave, so I replied: 'Go screw yourself!'

additional_notes: It's a colloquial and less polite way to tell someone to leave or stop bothering you. While it's common in casual French, be cautious as it can be considered rude.
target_language_example: Il était si ennuyeux que je lui ai dit : 'Va te faire voir !'
native_language_example: He was so annoying that I told him: 'Go away!'

additional_notes: Used in contexts related to space travel and science fiction. 'Vaisseau' means 'vessel' or 'ship', and 'spatial' means 'spatial'.
target_language_example: Le vaisseau spatial a atterri sur Mars.
native_language_example: The spaceship landed on Mars.

additional_notes: The phrase is often used to express whether an action or effort justifies the benefits received. It is typically used in conversation when weighing costs versus benefits or outcomes.
target_language_example: Ça vaut la peine d'essayer.
native_language_example: It's worth trying.

additional_notes: Used when determining if the benefits of an action outweigh the costs or effort.
target_language_example: Ce film vaut vraiment le coup d'être vu.
native_language_example: This movie is really worth seeing.

meaning: 'to be better' or 'it would be better'.
additional_notes: Used to suggest that a particular action or option is preferable over others. Often followed by an infinitive verb.
target_language_example: Il vaut mieux partir tôt pour éviter le traffic.
native_language_example: It's better to leave early to avoid traffic.

additional_notes: This phrase is informal and often used in spoken French. It literally translates to 'go there,' but it is commonly used to encourage someone to take action.
target_language_example: Tu veux essayer ? Vas-y !
native_language_example: Do you want to try? Go for it!

meaning: 'to spill the beans' or 'to reveal a secret'.
additional_notes: This phrase literally translates to 'sell the wick', but idiomatically it means to reveal something secret or confidential, often by accident or prematurely.
target_language_example: Il a vendu la mèche sur notre projet surprise.
native_language_example: He spilled the beans about our surprise project.

meaning: 'to come pick up' or 'to come and get'.
additional_notes: Used to describe the action of going to a place to collect or fetch someone or something. It's a common term for arranging to pick someone up, like from an airport, school, or another location.
target_language_example: Je vais venir chercher les enfants à l'école.
native_language_example: I will come and pick up the kids at school.

meaning: to have just done; to come from
additional_notes: With an infinitive, it expresses the recent past (Je viens de manger = I just ate). With a noun, it states origin (Je viens de Paris = I come from Paris). Conjugate venir, then add de + infinitive/place.
target_language_example: Je viens de finir mes devoirs.
native_language_example: I just finished my homework.

meaning: 'to help' or 'to come to the aid of'.
additional_notes: This phrase is commonly used in situations where someone extends help or support to another in need.
target_language_example: Les pompiers sont venus en aide aux victimes.
native_language_example: The firefighters came to the aid of the victims.

additional_notes: Used to describe when a thought, idea, or memory suddenly occurs to someone.
target_language_example: Un souvenir d'enfance m'est venu à l'esprit.
native_language_example: A childhood memory came to mind.

additional_notes: It describes a type of worm that lives in the soil and is commonly found in gardens.
target_language_example: Les enfants ont trouvé un ver de terre après la pluie.
native_language_example: The children found an earthworm after the rain.

additional_notes: This term is used to refer to the larva of the silk moth, which produces and spins silk as it constructs its cocoon. It’s a key concept in textile and fashion industries.
target_language_example: Le ver à soie produit des cocons utilisés pour fabriquer de la soie.
native_language_example: The silkworm produces cocoons used to make silk.

additional_notes: A viceroy is a person appointed to govern a country or province as the representative of the monarch. This term is historically tied to colonial rule.
target_language_example: Le vice-roi administra la colonie avec sagesse.
native_language_example: The viceroy governed the colony wisely.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used in religious or philosophical discussions about what happens after we die, covering concepts like heaven, reincarnation, or the afterlife.
target_language_example: Beaucoup de cultures croient en une vie après la mort.
native_language_example: Many cultures believe in a life after death.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to refer to personal matters that are not intended to be disclosed to the public or are part of someone's personal space.
target_language_example: Il préfère garder sa vie privée discrète.
native_language_example: He prefers to keep his private life discreet.

additional_notes: Used to talk about routine activities or daily routines and can encompass work, family, hobbies, and personal care activities.
target_language_example: Elle documente sa vie quotidienne sur son blog.
native_language_example: She documents her daily life on her blog.

additional_notes: Historically used to describe older unmarried women, but can carry negative connotations. Use carefully and be mindful of context and audience.
target_language_example: Elle est restée vieille fille toute sa vie.
native_language_example: She remained a spinster all her life.

additional_notes: Used to describe the historic part of a city, often characterized by narrow streets and aged buildings.
target_language_example: Nous allons visiter la vieille ville cet après-midi.
native_language_example: We are going to visit the old town this afternoon.

additional_notes: This term is typically used to express admiration for traditional methods or values. It emphasizes a respect or fondness for older ways of doing things.
target_language_example: Il aime le jazz de la vieille école.
native_language_example: He likes old school jazz.

additional_notes: Used to describe something or someone sticking to outdated ways or styles. Can apply to fashion, technology, or ideas.
target_language_example: Son style vestimentaire est un peu vieux jeu.
native_language_example: His clothing style is a bit old-fashioned.

additional_notes: Commonly used in French-speaking regions asking for wine or on menus.
target_language_example: Je vais prendre un verre de vin blanc.
native_language_example: I'll have a glass of white wine.

additional_notes: 'Vin rouge' is an essential term for anyone interested in French cuisine and dining culture, as wine is a staple in many meals.
target_language_example: Je préfère le vin rouge au vin blanc.
native_language_example: I prefer red wine over white wine.

additional_notes: Used to express the number 25 in French. Commonly used for counting, prices, and quantities.
target_language_example: J'ai vingt-cinq ans.
native_language_example: I am twenty-five years old.

additional_notes: Used to express the number 29 in counting, dates, quantities, etc.
target_language_example: J'ai vingt-neuf ans.
native_language_example: I am twenty-nine years old.

additional_notes: Used in contexts involving counting, time, dates, or ages. French numbers are important to know for engaging in basic conversations and transactions.
target_language_example: Le film commence à vingt-quatre heures.
native_language_example: The movie starts at 24:00.

additional_notes: This expression is used to describe services, stores, or activities that are available all the time, without interruption.
target_language_example: Le supermarché est ouvert vingt-quatre heures sur vingt-quatre.
native_language_example: The supermarket is open twenty-four hours a day.

additional_notes: Commonly used in counting, giving ages, dates, addressing, and phone numbers.
target_language_example: J'ai vingt-six ans.
native_language_example: I am twenty-six years old.

additional_notes: It is often used to indicate a comparison or relationship between two things. In English, it carries the meaning of comparing or contrasting one thing with another.
target_language_example: Nous devons examiner la situation économique vis-à-vis des objectifs de l'entreprise.
native_language_example: We need to examine the economic situation in relation to the company's objectives.

additional_notes: Used to compare or make a relation between subjects or topics. Common in both formal and informal conversations.
target_language_example: J'ai des questions vis-à-vis de votre proposition.
native_language_example: I have questions in relation to your proposal.

additional_notes: It is used in contexts related to nutrition, health, and medicine. Important for eyesight, immune function, and skin health.
target_language_example: Les carottes sont riches en vitamine A.
native_language_example: Carrots are rich in vitamin A.

additional_notes: A nutrient important for healthy skin and a strong immune system, often found in fruits like oranges and lemons.
target_language_example: Les oranges sont riches en vitamine C.
native_language_example: Oranges are rich in vitamin C.

additional_notes: Often used in informal contexts to describe an action completed quickly and sometimes superficially.
target_language_example: Il a fait ça vite fait avant de partir.
native_language_example: He did that quickly before leaving.

additional_notes: Often used in contexts related to train travel or rail transport infrastructure. It is an essential term for anyone discussing public transportation in French-speaking countries.
target_language_example: Il y a une voie ferrée qui passe par le village.
native_language_example: There is a railway track that goes through the village.

additional_notes: Used to introduce or explain a method or way of doing something. It often comes before a demonstration or explanation of a process.
target_language_example: Voilà comment on fait un gâteau.
native_language_example: This is how you make a cake.

additional_notes: Used to indicate that everything relevant has been said or done, and nothing more needs to be added.
target_language_example: J'ai fini le rapport, voilà tout.
native_language_example: I've finished the report, that's all.

additional_notes: Used to suggest verifying or consulting with someone about something. Often used to coordinate actions or decisions.
target_language_example: Je vais voir avec Marie pour savoir si elle est disponible.
native_language_example: I will check with Marie to see if she is available.

additional_notes: This phrase can be used both literally, as in having clear vision, or metaphorically, to describe the ability to understand or gain insight into a situation.
target_language_example: Je ne vois plus clair dans cette affaire.
native_language_example: I can no longer see clearly in this matter.

additional_notes: Used when someone is encouraged to be ambitious or to aim for large-scale goals or achievements.
target_language_example: Il faut voir grand pour réussir dans la vie.
native_language_example: You have to think big to succeed in life.

voir le bon côté des choses

target_language_multi_word_term: voir le bon côté des choses
meaning: to see the bright side of things.
additional_notes: This phrase encourages optimism and looking for the positive aspects in any situation. It is commonly used to support friends or family when things don't go as planned.
target_language_example: Même si c'était un échec, essayons de voir le bon côté des choses.
native_language_example: Even though it was a failure, let's try to see the bright side of things.

additional_notes: Commonly used to express a sense of caution or pragmatism, when someone prefers to observe how things develop before making a decision or acting.
target_language_example: Pour l'instant, nous allons voir venir avant de décider.
native_language_example: For now, we'll wait and see before deciding.

additional_notes: Used to get the listener's confirmation or to ensure understanding. It can be rhetorical in nature and adds emphasis to what is being said, similar to 'right?' or 'you know?' in English.
target_language_example: Il reste très peu de temps, vois-tu?
native_language_example: There's very little time left, you see?

additional_notes: Often used when discussing travel plans or transportation options. It refers to a car available for temporary use in exchange for payment.
target_language_example: Nous avons réservé une voiture de location pour notre voyage.
native_language_example: We have booked a rental car for our trip.

additional_notes: Refers to a high-performance car designed for speed, agility, and driving pleasure, often with a sleek look.
target_language_example: Il rêve d'acheter une voiture de sport un jour.
native_language_example: He dreams of buying a sports car one day.

additional_notes: This term is used frequently in discussions about sustainable transportation and technology innovation.
target_language_example: De plus en plus de gens achètent des voitures électriques pour réduire leur empreinte carbone.
native_language_example: More and more people are buying electric cars to reduce their carbon footprint.

additional_notes: Refers to a person who stealthily steals from others' pockets or bags, often in crowded places.
target_language_example: Faites attention aux voleurs à la tire dans le métro.
native_language_example: Watch out for pickpockets in the subway.

additional_notes: 'Volley-ball' is a direct translation from English and refers to the sport played by two teams on a rectangular court divided by a net.
target_language_example: Je joue au volley-ball tous les samedis.
native_language_example: I play volleyball every Saturday.

meaning: 'to be willing to', 'to be happy to'.
additional_notes: Used to politely agree to do something or to express a willingness to comply. It can add a tone of graciousness or cooperation.
target_language_example: Je veux bien t'aider avec ton projet.
native_language_example: I am happy to help you with your project.

additional_notes: Commonly used when asking for an explanation or interpretation of words, phrases, or actions. It helps clarify misunderstandings.
target_language_example: Qu'est-ce que tu veux dire par là?
native_language_example: What do you mean by that?

additional_notes: Commonly used in informal conversations to address groups of people. This construction is more emphasized in some French-speaking regions.
target_language_example: Alors, vous autres, qu'est-ce que vous allez faire ce week-end ?
native_language_example: So, you guys, what are you going to do this weekend?

additional_notes: Used when addressing someone formally or more than one person. It can introduce a question ("Do you know…") or serve as a filler to give emphasis or soften a statement.
target_language_example: Vous savez, il vaudrait mieux partir tôt pour éviter les embouteillages.
native_language_example: You know, it would be better to leave early to avoid traffic.

additional_notes: Used when about to reveal something surprising, interesting, or emphasizing a point. It can start a new topic or add emphasis to a statement.
target_language_example: Vous savez quoi ? J'ai gagné à la loterie !
native_language_example: You know what? I won the lottery!

additional_notes: Used to emphasize the person being addressed, often in formal or polite contexts. It can be used to encourage someone to participate, or it can be used to emphasize that the person should take action on their own.
target_language_example: Vous pouvez le faire vous-même.
native_language_example: You can do it yourself.

additional_notes: Emphasizes the subject 'you' in a sentence, indicating that the people being addressed should consider or act for themselves, usually in a formal or plural context.
target_language_example: Vous devez le faire vous-mêmes.
native_language_example: You must do it yourselves.

additional_notes: Used in professional contexts when referring to travel undertaken for work-related purposes.
target_language_example: Je pars en voyage d'affaires à Tokyo la semaine prochaine.
native_language_example: I am going on a business trip to Tokyo next week.

additional_notes: This term is commonly used in discussions involving science fiction, movies, or books related to travel through time.
target_language_example: Je veux faire un voyage dans le temps pour voir le futur.
native_language_example: I want to travel through time to see the future.

additional_notes: Used to politely ensure that someone understands or agrees with what was said. Common in formal or respectful contexts.
target_language_example: Voyez-vous ce que je veux dire ?
native_language_example: Do you see what I mean?

additional_notes: This phrase is often used when someone is considering their options, thinking something over, or about to verify information. It's a casual and conversational expression.
target_language_example: Voyons voir ce que nous avons ici.
native_language_example: Let's see what we have here.

additional_notes: Used to refer to actual, everyday experiences as opposed to fictional or imagined scenarios.
target_language_example: Dans la vraie vie, les choses ne sont pas toujours simples.
native_language_example: In real life, things are not always simple.

additional_notes: Generally refers to the days at the end of the week, typically Saturday and Sunday.
target_language_example: On va au cinéma le week-end.
native_language_example: We go to the movies on the weekend.

meaning: 'there's only that' or 'that's all there is'.
additional_notes: This phrase is informal and often used to express that there is no other choice or option. It's a shortened form of 'il n'y a que ça'.
target_language_example: Pour le dîner, il y a que ça.
native_language_example: For dinner, there's only that.

additional_notes: Combines the adverbial pronoun "y" (there) with "aller" (to go). Used for leaving a place or starting an action; in casual speech it can also mean "to go for it."
target_language_example: Il est tard, on doit y aller.
native_language_example: It’s late, we have to go.

additional_notes: Appears mainly in the expression "il y a" (and its tense or negative variations) to state the existence or presence of something. Works for singular and plural: "il y a" never changes form inside a sentence.
target_language_example: Il y a trois chats dans le jardin.
native_language_example: There are three cats in the garden.

additional_notes: Used to indicate inclusion of specific items within a broader category or list.
target_language_example: Tous les étudiants, y compris les nouveaux inscrits, doivent assister à la réunion.
native_language_example: All students, including new enrollees, must attend the meeting.

meaning: 'to count on it' or 'rely on that.'
additional_notes: It is used when expressing trust or reliance on something or someone. Typically used informally to assure or confirm reliability.
target_language_example: Tu peux y compter, il nous aidera.
native_language_example: You can count on it, he will help us.

additional_notes: The phrase is often used when expressing disbelief, doubt, or when being encouraged to have faith or confidence in something.
target_language_example: Je dois y croire, même si c'est difficile.
native_language_example: I have to believe in it, even if it's difficult.

additional_notes: Used in informal contexts. The 'y' generally refers to a figurative place 'beyond life' or 'the afterlife'. This phrase can be used when discussing someone who has recently died or an impending death.
target_language_example: Il était très malade, et malheureusement, il a fini par y passer.
native_language_example: He was very sick, and unfortunately, he ended up passing away.

additional_notes: Commonly used in expressions relating to dangers or accidents, implying that someone might die or barely escaped death.
target_language_example: Il a failli y rester dans cet accident de voiture.
native_language_example: He almost lost his life in that car accident.

additional_notes: Used to express that someone is prepared or all set to do something. It can also imply understanding a concept or being up-to-date with something.
target_language_example: Tu as tout ce qu'il te faut ? Oui, j'y suis !
native_language_example: Do you have everything you need? Yes, I'm ready!

additional_notes: This abbreviation stands for 'États-Unis' and is used in written contexts. It is also common in news articles and international discourse.
target_language_example: Les É.-U. sont connus pour leur diversité culturelle.
native_language_example: The U.S. is known for its cultural diversity.

additional_notes: This expression is often used in protests or political contexts to rally against a person, idea, or regime.
target_language_example: À bas la tyrannie!
native_language_example: Down with tyranny!

additional_notes: Used to specify the main ingredient or foundational aspect of an item.
target_language_example: J'ai préparé un dîner à base de légumes frais.
native_language_example: I prepared a dinner made from fresh vegetables.

additional_notes: Used when parting ways with someone to indicate you will meet again in the near future. Common in casual conversations.
target_language_example: Merci pour le café, à bientôt !
native_language_example: Thanks for the coffee, see you soon!

additional_notes: Used to describe something that is empty or without embellishments. Also, may refer to practice with blanks (e.g., in firearms) or cooking without any added sauces.
target_language_example: Il a imprimé le document à blanc.
native_language_example: He printed the document blank.

additional_notes: "À bloc" is typically used to describe an activity being done with maximum effort or capacity. It can be used in many contexts, from sports to work, and emphasizes intensity or completeness.
target_language_example: Il travaille à bloc pour terminer le projet.
native_language_example: He is working flat out to finish the project.

additional_notes: Used to indicate that someone or something is on a ship, aircraft, train, or other vehicles.
target_language_example: Les passagers sont à bord de l'avion.
native_language_example: The passengers are on board the plane.

additional_notes: Typically used to express that someone is emotionally or physically exhausted and can no longer handle a situation.
target_language_example: Je suis à bout de nerfs après cette longue semaine.
native_language_example: I am at the end of my tether after this long week.

additional_notes: Commonly used to express being at the end of one's patience or endurance. It often precedes words like 'force' (strength) or 'nerfs' (nerves).
target_language_example: Je suis à bout de forces après cette longue journée.
native_language_example: I am at the end of my strength after this long day.

additional_notes: While it can literally refer to being physically out of breath, it is often used metaphorically for being weary or exhausted from an effort or challenge.
target_language_example: Après la course, je suis à bout de souffle.
native_language_example: After the run, I am out of breath.

additional_notes: Used to indicate a reason, often implying blame or a negative consequence.
target_language_example: Nous avons été en retard à cause de l'embouteillage.
native_language_example: We were late because of the traffic jam.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used in formal or semi-formal contexts to indicate the present moment or to describe the present state of affairs. It can be used to describe progress, changes, or the current status of a particular matter.
target_language_example: À ce jour, nous n'avons reçu aucune réponse.
native_language_example: To date, we have not received any response.

additional_notes: Used to reference a specific point in the past. Often employed in narratives or recounting past events to specify when something happened.
target_language_example: Il pleuvait beaucoup à ce moment-là.
native_language_example: It was raining a lot at that time.

additional_notes: Used to transition or build upon a topic that has been mentioned earlier.
target_language_example: À ce propos, as-tu lu le livre dont je t'ai parlé ?
native_language_example: On this subject, have you read the book I told you about?

additional_notes: Used to refer to the current level or moment in a process or situation. Often used in discussions or descriptions of progress.
target_language_example: À ce stade, nous devons prendre une décision.
native_language_example: At this stage, we need to make a decision.

additional_notes: Used when referencing a specific topic or issue in conversation or writing.
target_language_example: Je n'ai rien à ajouter à ce sujet.
native_language_example: I have nothing to add on this subject.

additional_notes: Can be used literally to talk about the current hour of the day, or figuratively to refer to a specific moment or period in time, emphasizing the conditions or events associated with it.
target_language_example: À cette heure, tout le monde est déjà parti.
native_language_example: At this time, everyone has already left.

additional_notes: Commonly used in legal, financial, or contractual contexts to indicate someone who is responsible for a cost, duty, or obligation.
target_language_example: Les réparations sont à charge du locataire.
native_language_example: The repairs are the tenant's responsibility.

meaning: 'in the heat of the moment' or 'reacting immediately'.
additional_notes: This term is often used to describe an immediate reaction or decision made without much thought or deliberation right after an event takes place.
target_language_example: Il a répondu à chaud sans réfléchir.
native_language_example: He responded in the heat of the moment without thinking.

additional_notes: Literally used for riding a horse, but also metaphorically to describe being in between two positions or decisions.
target_language_example: Elle est partie à cheval pour explorer la campagne.
native_language_example: She left on horseback to explore the countryside.

additional_notes: Used to describe someone who adheres closely to rules or specifications, often showing precision or inflexibility.
target_language_example: Il est à cheval sur l'horaire.
native_language_example: He is strict about the schedule.

meaning: against the flow or against the current.
additional_notes: It is used to describe actions, thoughts, or behaviors that go against the majority or established norms.
target_language_example: Il a toujours aimé aller à contre-courant et penser différemment.
native_language_example: He has always liked going against the flow and thinking differently.

additional_notes: This phrase is used when someone does something they don't really want to do, but feel obliged or forced to do it.
target_language_example: Il a accepté la proposition à contrecœur.
native_language_example: He accepted the proposal reluctantly.

additional_notes: Often used informally to express achieving something with a certain tool or method used persistently or in large quantities.
target_language_example: Il l'a réparé à coup de marteau.
native_language_example: He fixed it using a hammer.

additional_notes: Used to describe something so impressive or beautiful that it figuratively 'takes your breath away'. Commonly used in admiration of art, nature, or achievements.
target_language_example: La vue du sommet de la montagne est à couper le souffle.
native_language_example: The view from the top of the mountain is breathtaking.

additional_notes: Often used to describe how something is accomplished, especially with repeated actions or the use of specific tools or means.
target_language_example: Il a réussi à coups de courage.
native_language_example: He succeeded by means of courage.

additional_notes: This term is commonly used with various nouns to indicate a lack or shortage, such as 'à court d'argent' (short of money) or 'à court de temps' (running out of time).
target_language_example: Je suis à court de sucre.
native_language_example: I am short of sugar.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used in informal contexts to express how something is so cute or charming that it could make someone metaphorically 'crack' from the sweetness or appeal.
target_language_example: Ce chaton est mignon à craquer.
native_language_example: This kitten is irresistibly cute.

additional_notes: Used to indicate that a purchase is made with a promise to pay later, often involves an agreement with a financial institution or store.
target_language_example: J'ai acheté la voiture à crédit.
native_language_example: I bought the car on credit.

additional_notes: Used to describe the position of something or someone relative to another object or person. Often followed by 'de' when specifying what it is next to.
target_language_example: La pharmacie est à côté de la boulangerie.
native_language_example: The pharmacy is next to the bakery.

additional_notes: Used to describe the position of an object or person in reference to another object or person. Commonly used in directions and spatial descriptions.
target_language_example: La bibliothèque est à côté de la mairie.
native_language_example: The library is next to the town hall.

additional_notes: Commonly used in idiomatic expressions to emphasize genuine feelings or something regarded with sincerity and deep affection.
target_language_example: Elle a toujours gardé cet endroit à cœur.
native_language_example: She always kept this place close to her heart.

additional_notes: Used to express disbelief or doubt about what someone is saying, implying that the speaker doesn't believe the story or excuse and suggests that others might be more gullible.
target_language_example: Tu as fini tout le travail en une heure ? À d'autres !
native_language_example: You finished all the work in an hour? Tell it to someone else!

additional_notes: It's used when parting with someone with the expectation of meeting again the following day. Suitable for informal and casual contexts.
target_language_example: Je dois y aller. À demain!
native_language_example: I have to go. See you tomorrow!

additional_notes: Used to indicate something done half-heartedly or to describe partial completion of an action or state.
target_language_example: Elle a terminé le travail à demi.
native_language_example: She finished the work halfway.

additional_notes: Commonly appears on transport schedules and announcements to specify locations where transportation is headed.
target_language_example: Le train est à destination de Paris.
native_language_example: The train is headed to Paris.

additional_notes: This phrase is often used to introduce a statement where the speaker wants to emphasize honesty or sincerity. It's commonly seen in speeches or explanations when clarifying or confessing.
target_language_example: À dire la vérité, je pense que c'est une mauvaise idée.
native_language_example: To tell the truth, I think it's a bad idea.

additional_notes: Commonly used in modern contexts such as remote work (travail à distance) or remote learning (apprentissage à distance).
target_language_example: Elle travaille à distance depuis chez elle.
native_language_example: She works remotely from home.

additional_notes: Used to indicate direction, useful in navigation and giving directions. Often used in contexts like driving, walking, or positioning.
target_language_example: Tournez à droite au prochain feu.
native_language_example: Turn right at the next light.

meaning: 'in the absence of' or 'for lack of'.
additional_notes: Used to express an alternative or to indicate that something is done because the preferred or expected thing is not available.
target_language_example: Nous irons à la plage, à défaut de pouvoir aller à la montagne.
native_language_example: We will go to the beach, for lack of being able to go to the mountains.

additional_notes: Commonly used to describe emotions that are close to the surface, like 'à fleur de peau' for 'hypersensitive' or 'at the edge of one's nerves'.
target_language_example: Elle est à fleur de peau aujourd'hui.
native_language_example: She is hypersensitive today.

additional_notes: Used to indicate that something is being done to the utmost extent, whether it be filling something completely or engaging in an activity with full effort.
target_language_example: Il a étudié à fond pour l'examen.
native_language_example: He studied thoroughly for the exam.

additional_notes: Used to indicate persistence or repetition over time that leads to a certain outcome. Often implies a sense of inevitability due to the repeated effort or pressure applied.
target_language_example: À force d'étudier, il a réussi ses examens.
native_language_example: Through persistent studying, he passed his exams.

meaning: 'by doing something repeatedly' or 'through repeated effort'.
additional_notes: This phrase suggests continuous effort or persistence. It's used to indicate that a result is achieved through sustained effort or repetition over time.
target_language_example: À force de pratiquer, il a amélioré son accent.
native_language_example: By practicing repeatedly, he improved his accent.

additional_notes: Often used to describe an analysis or action done after the fact, implying that there is a level of objectivity or lack of immediate emotional influence.
target_language_example: Il a analysé la situation à froid après quelques jours.
native_language_example: He analyzed the situation calmly after a few days.

additional_notes: Used to indicate direction or position in terms of left.
target_language_example: Tournez à gauche après le feu.
native_language_example: Turn left after the light.

additional_notes: Used to describe a literal physical position or in a more figurative sense to indicate submission or pleading.
target_language_example: Il est tombé à genoux pour demander pardon.
native_language_example: He fell on his knees to ask for forgiveness.

additional_notes: Used to describe something that is advancing with speed, often in the context of time or events happening soon.
target_language_example: L'été arrive à grand pas.
native_language_example: Summer is coming quickly.

additional_notes: This expression is used to describe rapid progress or movement. It often implies significant strides or advancements in a short amount of time.
target_language_example: Les progrès technologiques avancent à grands pas.
native_language_example: Technological progress is advancing quickly.

additional_notes: 'À haute voix' is often used when referring to reading or speaking so that others can hear. It emphasizes audibility.
target_language_example: Peux-tu lire ce texte à haute voix, s'il te plaît ?
native_language_example: Can you read this text out loud, please?

meaning: 'up to', 'at the level of', or 'to the amount of'.
additional_notes: Often used to specify a financial amount or a certain level/height in various contexts.
target_language_example: Les réparations coûteront à hauteur de 500 euros.
native_language_example: The repairs will cost up to 500 euros.

additional_notes: Used to describe something intended to last indefinitely or to convey a sense of permanence.
target_language_example: Je te promets de t'aimer à jamais.
native_language_example: I promise to love you forever.

additional_notes: This phrase is commonly used in contexts such as keeping information, systems, or knowledge current. It can also relate to updating documents or software.
target_language_example: Je suis à jour avec mes devoirs.
native_language_example: I am up-to-date with my homework.

additional_notes: Used to express that something is deservedly or correctly deemed a certain way, such as a reaction, a feeling, or a judgment.
target_language_example: Elle a protesté, à juste titre, contre la décision.
native_language_example: She rightly protested against the decision.

additional_notes: Used to indicate that someone or something is safe or unseen, often from weather or harm. Particularly useful when discussing safety or weather conditions.
target_language_example: Nous sommes à l'abri de la pluie ici.
native_language_example: We are sheltered from the rain here.

additional_notes: Commonly used when someone is in distress or requires immediate help. Can be used alone or within sentences.
target_language_example: Il a crié à l'aide quand il est tombé.
native_language_example: He shouted for help when he fell.

additional_notes: Often used to describe both people and situations where someone feels relaxed or confident, without any discomfort or stress.
target_language_example: Je me sens à l'aise chez toi.
native_language_example: I feel comfortable at your place.

additional_notes: Often used to describe something done in a traditional or nostalgic manner. Commonly found in contexts like cooking (e.g., recipes) or style (e.g., clothing, design).
target_language_example: Elle prépare le pot-au-feu à l'ancienne.
native_language_example: She makes pot-au-feu in the traditional way.

additional_notes: This expression is used in contexts involving live radio or TV broadcasts. It suggests that someone is currently live and transmitting.
target_language_example: L'animateur est maintenant à l'antenne.
native_language_example: The host is now on the air.

additional_notes: Often used to discuss future plans or events. Can be used when talking about predictions or resolutions.
target_language_example: Je vais étudier plus à l'avenir.
native_language_example: I will study more in the future.

additional_notes: Used to describe objects, garments, or situations that are flipped or reversed from their proper orientation.
target_language_example: Il a mis son pull à l'envers.
native_language_example: He put his sweater on inside out.

additional_notes: Used to indicate something happening or located outside a certain place, as opposed to inside. Can be used in various contexts such as weather, location, or activities.
target_language_example: Il fait froid à l'extérieur.
native_language_example: It's cold outside.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to confirm or describe someone's punctuality.
target_language_example: Il est toujours à l'heure.
native_language_example: He is always on time.

additional_notes: Used to describe something that happened very recently or is happening in the immediate present.
target_language_example: Il est parti à l'instant.
native_language_example: He just left.

additional_notes: Used to describe something that is contained or enclosed within another object or space. Can be used both in a literal sense (inside a room) or figuratively (inside a situation).
target_language_example: Il y a un chat à l'intérieur de la boîte.
native_language_example: There is a cat inside the box.

additional_notes: Used to describe the physical location of something being inside an area or object. Commonly used in everyday situations.
target_language_example: La clé est à l'intérieur de la boîte.
native_language_example: The key is inside the box.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to describe events that happen infrequently or not on a regular schedule.
target_language_example: Nous mangeons au restaurant à l'occasion.
native_language_example: We eat at the restaurant occasionally.

additional_notes: Used to describe someone who is genuinely paying attention or is open to hearing others' thoughts or concerns.
target_language_example: Elle est toujours à l'écoute de ses amis.
native_language_example: She is always listening to her friends.

additional_notes: Commonly used when recalling events or conditions in the past. It can be used to contrast past events with the present.
target_language_example: À l'époque, nous n'avions pas de téléphone portable.
native_language_example: At that time, we didn't have mobile phones.

additional_notes: It is often used to describe location within a building, typically meaning on the upper floors. It helps in navigating locations within multi-story buildings, like homes, apartments, or offices.
target_language_example: La chambre est à l'étage.
native_language_example: The bedroom is upstairs.

additional_notes: Commonly used to describe situations involving travel to or from foreign countries. It can also be used to describe someone or something that is from or located outside one's home country.
target_language_example: Elle étudie à l'étranger cette année.
native_language_example: She is studying abroad this year.

additional_notes: This phrase is informal and is used when something is acquired without any payment. It is commonly used in everyday conversation when talking about receiving something at no cost.
target_language_example: J'ai obtenu ce billet de concert à l'œil.
native_language_example: I got this concert ticket for free.

additional_notes: Often used to describe someone actively doing something, whether it's a creative, professional, or physical task.
target_language_example: Les artistes sont à l'œuvre dans l'atelier.
native_language_example: The artists are at work in the studio.

additional_notes: Placed before a noun or adjective to show something is prepared, served, or done in the manner of that reference. Often used in food (à la provençale) or more generally (à la Sherlock Holmes).
target_language_example: J’ai préparé le poulet à la provençale.
native_language_example: I prepared the chicken Provençal-style.

additional_notes: Often used in legal contexts to refer to someone standing before a judge or jury. Can also indicate someone taking leadership or control in other contexts, such as steering a ship.
target_language_example: L'avocat est à la barre pour défendre son client.
native_language_example: The lawyer is at the bar to defend his client.

additional_notes: Often used to discuss a plan or intention that has changed from its original form.
target_language_example: À la base, je voulais devenir médecin.
native_language_example: Originally, I wanted to become a doctor.

meaning: 'under the stars' or 'out in the open'.
additional_notes: This phrase refers to sleeping outdoors, without shelter, in a beautiful natural setting typically under a clear sky. It evokes romantic or adventurous scenarios and is often used in literature and conversation about camping or spending a night under the open sky.
target_language_example: Nous avons passé la nuit à la belle étoile pendant notre randonnée.
native_language_example: We spent the night under the stars during our hike.

meaning: 'on the inside track' or 'close to the rope'.
additional_notes: This phrase is commonly used in competitive contexts where the shortest path gives a strategic advantage.
target_language_example: Le cheval est resté à la corde toute la course.
native_language_example: The horse stayed on the inside track for the entire race.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to describe actions or decisions taken very late, often implying haste or a lack of preparation time.
target_language_example: Il a terminé son projet à la dernière minute.
native_language_example: He finished his project at the last minute.

additional_notes: It indicates the conclusion of an event, action, or period of time. Can also imply finality or result of something.
target_language_example: À la fin du film, tout le monde a applaudi.
native_language_example: At the end of the movie, everyone applauded.

additional_notes: Commonly used to describe simultaneous actions or dual qualities.
target_language_example: Il est à la fois intelligent et drôle.
native_language_example: He is both intelligent and funny.

additional_notes: Used to express the competence or suitability of a person or thing in relation to a task or requirement.
target_language_example: Il faut être à la hauteur de la situation.
native_language_example: One must be up to the situation.

additional_notes: This term is often used to describe actions done quickly and sometimes carelessly, often implying a lack of thoroughness.
target_language_example: Il a terminé son travail à la hâte.
native_language_example: He finished his work in a hurry.

additional_notes: Typically used to discuss or reassess situations, decisions, or understandings after considering new information or context.
target_language_example: À la lumière de ces faits, nous devrons reconsidérer notre décision.
native_language_example: In light of these facts, we will have to reconsider our decision.

additional_notes: Used to indicate something done without sufficient thought or seriousness. It often carries a mildly negative connotation.
target_language_example: Il ne faut pas prendre cette décision à la légère.
native_language_example: You should not take this decision lightly.

additional_notes: This expression is used to describe things made manually, emphasizing the human touch involved in creating or doing something.
target_language_example: Ce pull a été tricoté à la main.
native_language_example: This sweater was knitted by hand.

additional_notes: Used for both location (being) and destination (going) when referring to one’s own or someone else’s home. Literally “at the house.”
target_language_example: Je reste à la maison ce soir.
native_language_example: I’m staying at home tonight.

additional_notes: It often implies a vulnerability or lack of control over a situation, where the outcome is dependent on the will or actions of others.
target_language_example: Les voyageurs étaient à la merci de la tempête.
native_language_example: The travelers were at the mercy of the storm.

meaning: 'in fashion' or 'with ice cream on top'.
additional_notes: In general conversation, it refers to something that is currently trendy or fashionable. In culinary terms, particularly in American English, it means a dessert served with ice cream.
target_language_example: Elle s'habille toujours à la mode.
native_language_example: She always dresses in fashion.

additional_notes: Used to describe someone or something that is stylish or current. Often applied to fashion or popular trends.
target_language_example: Elle est toujours à la page avec ses vêtements.
native_language_example: She is always fashionable with her clothes.

additional_notes: Used to describe actions or tasks performed flawlessly. Similar to 'to perfection' in English.
target_language_example: Elle a chanté la chanson à la perfection.
native_language_example: She sang the song perfectly.

additional_notes: Used to express the substitution of one thing for another. Can be used for both actions and objects.
target_language_example: Je prendrai du thé à la place du café.
native_language_example: I will have tea instead of coffee.

additional_notes: It is used to talk about replacing one thing with another, often in decision-making or when expressing preferences.
target_language_example: Je prendrai du thé à la place de café.
native_language_example: I will have tea instead of coffee.

additional_notes: Used to describe something that is understandable, achievable, or physically reachable by someone. It can refer to skills, knowledge, or physical items.
target_language_example: Ce livre est à la portée des débutants.
native_language_example: This book is within reach of beginners.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to suggest doing something at the very start of the day.
target_language_example: Je commencerai le projet à la première heure demain.
native_language_example: I will start the project first thing in the morning tomorrow.

meaning: 'until next time' or 'see you next time'.
additional_notes: Used informally as a farewell greeting when parting from friends, colleagues, or acquaintances, suggesting a future encounter.
target_language_example: On se voit au café demain ? À la prochaine !
native_language_example: Are we meeting at the café tomorrow? Until next time!

meaning: 'retired', referring to someone no longer working.
additional_notes: Used to describe someone who has stopped working, often due to reaching a certain age of retirement. It's commonly used in casual and formal discussions about job status.
target_language_example: Mon père est à la retraite depuis cinq ans.
native_language_example: My father has been retired for five years.

additional_notes: Used to describe someone who has no home and lives on the street. It can also be used metaphorically to indicate being in a difficult or hopeless situation.
target_language_example: Il est malheureusement à la rue depuis des mois.
native_language_example: He has unfortunately been homeless for months.

additional_notes: Often used to describe events happening one after another or in sequence. Can be used to indicate cause and effect relationships as well.
target_language_example: À la suite de l'incident, ils ont renforcé la sécurité.
native_language_example: Following the incident, they increased security.

additional_notes: Used during a toast to wish someone well. It's the informal singular version of the more formal 'à votre santé'.
target_language_example: À la tienne, mon ami !
native_language_example: To your health, my friend!

additional_notes: This expression can be used literally to describe someone who is slow or in a figurative sense to describe someone who is not keeping up with others in progress, performance, or trends.
target_language_example: Il est toujours à la traîne au travail.
native_language_example: He is always falling behind at work.

additional_notes: This expression is commonly used when someone is busy or engaged in their work, highlighting their commitment or concentration on the task at hand.
target_language_example: Elle est toujours à la tâche jusqu'à tard dans la nuit.
native_language_example: She is always at work until late at night.

meaning: 'on the front page' or 'in the headlines'.
additional_notes: This term is often used in journalistic contexts to indicate the main news or most prominent topic of the day in newspapers or other news media.
target_language_example: L'incendie dans la forêt est à la une aujourd'hui.
native_language_example: The forest fire is in the headlines today.

additional_notes: Used to describe a reaction, feeling, or event triggered by seeing something.
target_language_example: Elle a pâli à la vue du sang.
native_language_example: She turned pale at the sight of the blood.

additional_notes: Commonly said when clinking glasses, it is a polite way to express goodwill wishes towards others during a toast.
target_language_example: À la vôtre !
native_language_example: Cheers!

additional_notes: Used to discuss planning or effects that will be realized after a considerable amount of time.
target_language_example: Il faut penser à long terme pour nos investissements.
native_language_example: We must think in the long term for our investments.

additional_notes: Commonly found on signs or advertisements indicating that a property or item is available for rental purposes.
target_language_example: L'appartement est à louer.
native_language_example: The apartment is for rent.

additional_notes: Used to describe actions performed without any tools or equipment, often emphasizing raw strength or skills.
target_language_example: Il a combattu l'ours à mains nues.
native_language_example: He fought the bear with his bare hands.

additional_notes: This expression is often used to praise something or someone, indicating that something was done exceptionally well.
target_language_example: Elle a réussi son examen à merveille.
native_language_example: She passed her exam perfectly.

additional_notes: Used to indicate that something is happening or changing progressively in the same measure as another action or process. It often accompanies 'que' to form the expression 'à mesure que', which means 'as'.
target_language_example: Les arbres grandissent à mesure que le temps passe.
native_language_example: The trees grow as time passes.

additional_notes: Used to describe being at an equal distance between two points. Can be applied to physical location or metaphorically to indicate progress.
target_language_example: Nous sommes à mi-chemin de Paris.
native_language_example: We are halfway to Paris.

additional_notes: Often used to claim ownership or in expressions of personal association.
target_language_example: Ce livre est à moi.
native_language_example: This book is mine.

additional_notes: Commonly followed by a verb in the infinitive form or further specification of a condition or scenario. It indicates an exception or an alternative condition.
target_language_example: Je viendrai à ton anniversaire à moins de devoir travailler.
native_language_example: I will come to your birthday party unless I have to work.

additional_notes: Introduces a condition or exception. Often requires the use of the subjunctive mood in the following clause.
target_language_example: Je viendrai à la fête, à moins qu'il ne pleuve.
native_language_example: I will come to the party, unless it rains.

additional_notes: Often used to describe something being done to a partial extent or not entirely completed.
target_language_example: Elle a fait son travail à moitié.
native_language_example: She did her work partially.

additional_notes: This expression is used when giving a personal viewpoint or perspective on a topic.
target_language_example: À mon avis, ce film est excellent.
native_language_example: In my opinion, this movie is excellent.

additional_notes: Used in expressions indicating extreme intensity or a strong sentiment, often said in contexts like sports or support to show enthusiastic commitment.
target_language_example: On va les soutenir à mort.
native_language_example: We're going to support them wholeheartedly.

additional_notes: Common to say something is 'à même la peau' meaning directly on the skin, indicating direct contact.
target_language_example: Elle a appliqué la crème à même la peau.
native_language_example: She applied the cream directly on the skin.

additional_notes: This expression can be used both literally, as in physically leveling something, or figuratively, in terms of being equal in skills or standards.
target_language_example: Après beaucoup de pratique, il est maintenant à niveau avec les meilleurs joueurs.
native_language_example: After much practice, he is now on par with the best players.

additional_notes: Generally used to express doing something again with the implication of trying it in a new way or after a change, as opposed to simply repeating exactly as before.
target_language_example: Il a commencé son projet à nouveau.
native_language_example: He started his project again.

additional_notes: Used to exclude something from a general statement or to indicate a contrast or exception.
target_language_example: À part le dessert, tout était délicieux.
native_language_example: Apart from the dessert, everything was delicious.

additional_notes: It is often used to specify the starting time of an event or the starting price of something.
target_language_example: Le concert commence à partir de 20h.
native_language_example: The concert starts from 8 PM.

additional_notes: Often used to indicate that an action was completed but with difficulty, or that the amount is barely sufficient.
target_language_example: Il a à peine fini ses devoirs.
native_language_example: He has barely finished his homework.

additional_notes: Used when giving an estimate or indicating that a quantity or amount is not exact.
target_language_example: Il y a à peu près cinquante personnes dans la salle.
native_language_example: There are about fifty people in the room.

additional_notes: Used to describe things that are very steep or abrupt, like cliffs, or to express changes that occur very suddenly.
target_language_example: La falaise tombe à pic dans la mer.
native_language_example: The cliff drops steeply into the sea.

additional_notes: This term is used to describe traveling or moving somewhere by walking rather than by vehicle or other means of transport.
target_language_example: Je vais à l'école à pied.
native_language_example: I go to school on foot.

additional_notes: Used to describe something that is level with the surface, or metaphorically to indicate devices that are out of power or someone who is exhausted.
target_language_example: Mon téléphone est à plat.
native_language_example: My phone is out of battery.

additional_notes: Describes someone lying face down or can be used metaphorically to indicate submission.
target_language_example: Il était allongé à plat ventre sur le tapis.
native_language_example: He was lying flat on his stomach on the carpet.

additional_notes: Commonly used to describe situations or performances that are so poor that they cause disappointment or frustration.
target_language_example: Le film était tellement mauvais que c'était à pleurer.
native_language_example: The movie was so bad that it was pitiful.

additional_notes: This is an informal way to say goodbye and implies a future meeting, though it doesn't specify when. It's a short form of 'à plus tard'.
target_language_example: D'accord, à plus !
native_language_example: Alright, see you later!

additional_notes: Used when parting ways, indicating that you will meet or communicate again in the future.
target_language_example: Je dois y aller maintenant, à plus tard !
native_language_example: I have to go now, see you later!

additional_notes: Casual and informal; often used humorously or in a relaxed context to mean someone or something is not wearing any clothing.
target_language_example: Il est sorti de la chambre à poil.
native_language_example: He came out of the room naked.

additional_notes: Commonly used when referring to cooking meat, especially steak. It indicates a level where the meat is cooked through but still pink inside. Beyond food, it implies something done appropriately or at the right moment.
target_language_example: Je voudrais mon steak à point, s'il vous plaît.
native_language_example: I would like my steak medium rare, please.

additional_notes: Typically used when something occurs at a precise and convenient time; the expression adds emphasis on positive timing or coincidence.
target_language_example: Votre appel est arrivé à point nommé.
native_language_example: Your call came at just the right time.

additional_notes: This expression is used to describe something that is conveniently close or easy to access, both physically and metaphorically.
target_language_example: Le chargeur est à portée de main sur la table.
native_language_example: The charger is within reach on the table.

additional_notes: Used to describe an immediate impression or observation before deeper analysis or understanding takes place. Commonly used to express that an opinion is based on a superficial look.
target_language_example: À première vue, ce tableau semble ancien.
native_language_example: At first glance, this painting seems old.

additional_notes: Often used to introduce a topic or to reference something related to the current context. Can stand alone or be followed by 'de' when specifying what something is about.
target_language_example: À propos, as-tu entendu les nouvelles?
native_language_example: By the way, did you hear the news?

additional_notes: Often used to introduce the subject of discussion or the topic one is inquiring about.
target_language_example: Nous avons parlé à propos de son voyage.
native_language_example: We talked about his trip.

additional_notes: Used to indicate something (usually a place or object) is close by or not far away.
target_language_example: Il y a un café à proximité.
native_language_example: There is a café nearby.

additional_notes: Often used in formal contexts or in writing to indicate the current time or situation. It is synonymous with 'maintenant', which is more commonly used in casual speech.
target_language_example: À présent, il est trop tard pour changer d'avis.
native_language_example: Now, it is too late to change your mind.

additional_notes: Commonly used to describe crawling, especially concerning babies and some animals.
target_language_example: Le bébé avance à quatre pattes.
native_language_example: The baby is crawling on all fours.

additional_notes: Used to quantify or inquire about the degree of something, typically an emotion, opinion, or state.
target_language_example: À quel point est-il important pour toi ?
native_language_example: How important is it to you?

additional_notes: This phrase is often used to express resignation or skepticism about the value or sense of doing something.
target_language_example: À quoi bon se lever si tôt si on n'a rien à faire ?
native_language_example: What's the point of getting up so early if there's nothing to do?

additional_notes: Used to express a proportion or rate, often in contexts involving units, speed, or frequency.
target_language_example: Le train roule à raison de 200 kilomètres par heure.
native_language_example: The train is moving at the rate of 200 kilometers per hour.

additional_notes: Used to indicate that a container (e.g., a cup, glass, or bowl) is filled to the edge, leaving no space inside.
target_language_example: La tasse de café est remplie à ras bord.
native_language_example: The coffee mug is filled to the brim.

additional_notes: Often used to describe appearance, performance, or actions in a very positive way, implying great joy or charm.
target_language_example: Elle était habillée à ravir pour la soirée.
native_language_example: She was dressed exquisitely for the evening.

additional_notes: Can be used when discussing time, order, or processes that go from end to start, like a countdown or tracing back steps.
target_language_example: Il a lu le livre à rebours pour comprendre la fin.
native_language_example: He read the book backwards to understand the end.

additional_notes: Often used for vehicles or engines, like 'moteur à réaction' (jet engine). It describes devices or systems using the principle of propulsion by expelling high-velocity gases.
target_language_example: Cet avion est à réaction.
native_language_example: This airplane is jet-powered.

additional_notes: Used to elaborate or specify particular things from a general statement.
target_language_example: Il y a trois solutions proposées, à savoir: la première, la deuxième, et la troisième.
native_language_example: There are three proposed solutions, namely: the first, the second, and the third.

additional_notes: Often used to describe a situation where someone has run out of resources, especially financially.
target_language_example: Après avoir payé les factures, il est à sec.
native_language_example: After paying the bills, he is broke.

additional_notes: This term is often paired with nouns to convey that they have achieved popularity or commercial success, like a book, film, or album.
target_language_example: Elle est l'auteure d'un livre à succès.
native_language_example: She is the author of a successful book.

additional_notes: Commonly found at the end of an episode or article, implying that there will be more to come. It is often seen in the context of serialized content.
target_language_example: L'épisode d'aujourd'hui était incroyable. À suivre dans le prochain épisode !
native_language_example: Today's episode was amazing. To be continued in the next episode!

additional_notes: Commonly used when clinking glasses during a toast. It is the informal singular form, so it is appropriate when addressing one person you are familiar with.
target_language_example: À ta santé, mon ami!
native_language_example: To your health, my friend!

additional_notes: Commonly used by hosts or family members to call everyone to the table for a meal, similar to saying 'dinner is ready' in English.
target_language_example: Les enfants, à table !
native_language_example: Kids, dinner is served!

additional_notes: Used to indicate that something is done or occurs at the expected or scheduled time, often in relation to appointments, work, etc.
target_language_example: Il est arrivé à temps pour la réunion.
native_language_example: He arrived on time for the meeting.

additional_notes: Used to describe work that is not full-time, typically with fewer hours per week.
target_language_example: Elle travaille à temps partiel dans un café.
native_language_example: She works part-time in a café.

additional_notes: Commonly used to describe employment or any activity done for the entire expected duration, as opposed to part-time.
target_language_example: Je travaille à temps plein dans une école.
native_language_example: I work full-time at a school.

additional_notes: Commonly used to describe something occurring after a certain period or at the completion of a term. Can be used in the context of financial investments or pregnancy.
target_language_example: Le projet sera terminé à terme.
native_language_example: The project will be finished eventually.

additional_notes: Used to describe something or someone being positioned on the ground or low level. It is versatile and can be used in everyday language as well as in specific contexts like dance or military.
target_language_example: Le papier est tombé à terre.
native_language_example: The paper fell to the ground.

additional_notes: Used to denote a position or function someone holds. It can often be found in professional and formal contexts.
target_language_example: Elle travaille à titre de consultante.
native_language_example: She works as a consultant.

additional_notes: It is often used to show possession or when addressing someone directly, such as when giving something to them or clarifying ownership.
target_language_example: C'est à toi ce livre ?
native_language_example: Is this book yours?

additional_notes: Often used in conversations to seek someone's personal viewpoint or judgment. It translates to asking for what someone personally thinks or believes.
target_language_example: À ton avis, quel est le meilleur film de l'année ?
native_language_example: In your opinion, what is the best movie of the year?

additional_notes: Used to describe an action or belief that is incorrect or unjustified.
target_language_example: Il a été accusé à tort.
native_language_example: He was wrongly accused.

additional_notes: This expression is often used to describe actions performed by multiple people taking turns, commonly used in various settings like classrooms, meetings, or games.
target_language_example: Ils ont parlé à tour de rôle pendant la réunion.
native_language_example: They spoke in turns during the meeting.

additional_notes: Used to emphasize that an outcome or action occurs predictably or repeatedly.
target_language_example: Pierre est en retard à tous les coups.
native_language_example: Pierre is late every time.

additional_notes: This phrase is used to indicate that something can occur at any unspecified time, and can be used in various contexts, both anticipated and unexpected events.
target_language_example: Il peut arriver à tout moment.
native_language_example: He can arrive at any time.

additional_notes: Indicates a strong determination to achieve a goal no matter the sacrifices needed. It often implies willingness to do whatever it takes.
target_language_example: Il veut réussir à tout prix.
native_language_example: He wants to succeed at all costs.

additional_notes: This phrase is informal and used often between friends, family, or colleagues to imply a short-term goodbye. It is less formal than 'au revoir,' which means 'goodbye.'
target_language_example: Je dois partir maintenant, mais à tout à l'heure !
native_language_example: I have to leave now, but see you later!

additional_notes: Informal way to say goodbye. Commonly used among friends or acquaintances when you are planning to see each other again soon.
target_language_example: Je dois y aller, à toute !
native_language_example: I have to go, see you later!

additional_notes: Often used to describe quick movement or rapid actions, indicating urgency or haste.
target_language_example: Les voitures passent à toute allure sur l'autoroute.
native_language_example: The cars are passing by very quickly on the highway.

additional_notes: This phrase highlights urgency or the swiftness of an action. It is used to emphasize that something is being done as fast as possible.
target_language_example: Il a couru à toute vitesse pour attraper le bus.
native_language_example: He ran very quickly to catch the bus.

additional_notes: Used to indicate movement from one side to another of an area, object, or time.
target_language_example: Il a regardé à travers la fenêtre.
native_language_example: He looked through the window.
